She needs the loan to purchase corn, potatoes and hens. Karina's dream is to have her own house and grow her business.

Karina pertenece al Banco Comunal Milenio hace 3 años.

Karina es conviviente, tiene 22 años y 1 hijo de 2 años, Karina viaja a las ferias de la región 2 veces por semana donde compra cereales, queso, animales menores y luego lo comercializa en la ciudad de Ayacucho a tiendas y mercados. Además Karina en algunas oportunidades trabaja pelando papa.

Karina necesita un préstamo de 1500 soles, dinero que será invertido en la compra de maíz, papa, gallina.

Los sueños de Karina son tener una casa propia y que su negocio mejore.

loans.use: TO PURCHASE CORN, POTATOES AND HENS FROM THE REGIONAL MARKETS, SO SHE CAN  SELL THEM IN THE SHOPS AND MARKETS IN HER CITY.

loans.name: Maribel's Group

texts.es:
Adela, Maribel have been members of the communal bank Azucenas for 1 year, and Pilar has been a member for 4 months. Adela is single and 38 years old, and takes care of her nephew who is under her charge. She makes cheeses which she sells in the community of Alpachaca. She also has some opportunities to sell clothing.

Maribel is 25 years old and married. Together with her husband, she makes pastries in an oven which they rent. They sell their pastries in the city of Lima and also in Ayacucho. And PIlar is 21 years old and single. Pilar sells grocery items and toys from her house.

Adela, Maribel and Pilar need these loans to invest in their respective businesses. PIlar dreams of having a big toy store one day, Adela would like to finish her studies and Mirabel would like to build their own house in Ayacucho and open their own bakery.

Adela, Maribel y Pilar pertenecen al Banco Comunal Azucenas hace 1 año, 1 año, 4 meses.

Adela es soltera y tiene 38 años, Adela tiene a su cuidado a su sobrino, Adela se dedica a la venta de quesos que ella misma elabora y compra de la comunidad de Alpachaca, Adela tiene ganado vacuno. Además en algunas oportunidades vende ropa.

Por otro lado Maribel es conviviente y tiene 25 años, Maribel junto a su esposo elaboran pasteles en un horno alquilado, sus productos los vende en la ciudad de Lima y también en Ayacucho.

Mientras que Pilar es soltera y tiene 21 años, Pilar vende abarrotes en su casa, además tiene juegos de mesa y tragamonedas.

Adela, Maribel y Pilar necesitan préstamos de 1000 soles, 400 soles, 400 soles, dinero que será invertido en la compra de ropa, para realizar el mantenimiento técnico de sus juegos y como parte de pago de una máquina batidora.

Los sueños de Adela, Maribel y Pilar son tener una tienda grande de juegos, culminar sus estudios y trabajar, construir su casa en la ciudad de Ayacucho, tener una panadería.

loans.use: TO INVEST IN THEIR RESPECTIVE BUSINESSES SELLING CLOTHING, BREAD, GROCERY ITEMS AND TOYS, AND CONTINUE TO IMPROVE THEIR QUALITY OF LIFE.

loans.name: Paula Isidora

texts.es:
Paula is from the Villa de Reconciliación neighborhood. She is 41 years-old and is married. Her husband supports her family working as a truck driver. They have three children, a 15 year-old, a 13 year-old, and a 7 month-old. It has been six years since AFODENIC began providing her with financial assistance to start a small grocery store. As with any business, sometimes sales are low, so she would like a loan to build a room for her children and to make home improvements. In the future she would like to make her home larger to improve her children’s lives.

Translated from Spanish by Joanna Silverman, Kiva Volunteer.

La Sra. Paula es del barrio Villa de Reconciliación con 41 años de edad es casada y su esposo es conductor de camión el cual aporta a su hogar le tienen tres hijos uno de 15, 13 y 7 meses el ultimo. Ella tiene seis años de experiencia el cual comenzó con prestamos en AFODENIC donde le brindaron el apoyo para comenzar con una pequeña pulpería, a veces las ventas son bajas, como todo negocio, el prestamos lo quiere para construir un cuarto para sus hijos y mejorar su vivienda, a futuro es hacer la estructura de su casa mas grande y contribuir al nivel de vida para sus hijos.

loans.use: Home Improvement

loans.name: Gloria

texts.es:
Mrs. C. lives in the neighborhood of “Villa de Reconciliacion”. She is 48 years old, married, and has 3 children. Two of them work in the construction business, and help her with the basic daily expenses. Mrs. C. is a seamstress (with six years of experience) who started her business with money that her husband gave her, and who is fighting to get ahead for her children. With this loan, she would like to build a bathroom and a kitchen in order to improve their home and their quality of life.

Translated from Spanish by Samantha, Kiva volunteer.

La Sra. C. habita en el barrio Villa de Reconciliación con 48 años de edad es casada con tres hijos, dos de ellos trabajan en la construcción y le ayudan para los gasto básico. Ella es costurera tiene seis años de experiencia luchando `para salir adelantes con sus hijos. Comenzó su negocio, con dinero que el esposo le dio, el préstamo lo va invertir para construir baños y cocina. Para dar aspecto a su vivienda y mejorar su nivel de vida.

loans.use: To improve her home.

payments.comment: scheduled_repayment (late autopay posting for AFODENIC - Oct 26, 2008)

loans.name: Nelida's Group

texts.es:
Yessy, Fabiana and Nelida have been members of the communal bank called Chacco for 2 years. They are from the community of Chacco which is located about 30 minutes outside of Ayacucho.

Yessy is 33 years old and married with one child. For two years she has had a small shop where she sells drinks. Fabiana is 38 years old and also married, with 3 children. She has a shop where she sells grocery items. She also grows vegetables which she sells in the market of Nery Garcia. And Nelida is 27 years old and married with 2 children. She works as a nurse but right now she is pregnant and not working. She also grows vegetables.

These women will use the loan to purchase stock for their businesses, such as sodas, beer, noodles, cooking oil, soap, seeds and fertilizers. They all share the dream of being successful professionals, improving their houses and growing their businesses.

Yessy, Fabiana y Nelida pertenecen al Banco Comunal Chacco hace 2 años. Ellas son de la comunidad de Chacco que esta ubicado a 30 minutos de la ciudad de Ayacucho.

Yessy es conviviente, tiene 33 años y 1 hija, Yessy es conviviente, tiene 33 años y 1 hija, Yessy tiene una tienda donde vende bebidas, actividad que realiza hace 2 años.

Por otro lado Fabiana es conviviente, tiene 38 años y 3 hijos, Fabiana tiene una tienda de abarrotes, además Fabiana se dedica a la agricultura de verduras que vende en el mercado Nery García.

Mientras que Nelida es conviviente, tiene 27 años y 2 hijos, Nelida es enfermera pero actualmente no esta trabajando por su embarazo. Nelida se dedica a la agricultura de verduras.

Yessy, Fabiana y Nelida necesitan préstamos de 900 soles, 1500 soles, 600 soles, dinero que será invertido en la compra de gaseosa, cerveza, fideo, aceite, jabón, semilla y abono.

Los sueños de Yessy, Fabiana y Nelida son que sus hijos sean profesionales, mejorar su casa y su negocio sea más grande.

loans.use: TO PURCHASE STOCK FOR THEIR RESPECTIVE BUSINESSES SUCH AS SODAS, BEER, NOODLES, OIL, SOAP, SEEDS AND FERTILIZERS.

payments.comment: Correction due to underpayment for business 46771

loans.name: Enedina Yolanda's Group

texts.es:
Alejandrina, Yolanda and Jossely have been members of the communal bank of Chacco for one year. They are from the community of Chacco which is located 30 minutes outside of Ayacucho.

Alejandrina is 49 years old and married with 4 children. She has a shop where she sells grocery items, and she also grows vegetables. Yolanda is 43 years old and widowed with 3 children. Yolanda travels to the city of Lima where she buys vegetables and clothing depending on the demand. She sells the vegetables in the Ayacucho market and she sells the clothing on credit in her community. And Jossely is single and 19 years old. She and her mother have a general store.

The women will use the loans to purchase sugar, noodles, milk, rice and tuna, as well as clothing to sell. They share the dream of growing their respective businesses, educating their children to be professionals, and improving their homes.

Alejandrina, Yolanda y Jossely pertenecen al Banco Comunal Chacco hace 1 año. Ellas son de la comunidad de Chacco que esta ubicado a 30 minutos de la ciudad de Ayacucho.

Alejandrina es casada, tiene 49 años y 4 hijos, Alejandrina tiene una tienda de abarrotes y además se dedica a la agricultura de verduras.

Por otro lado Yolanda es viuda, tiene 43 años y 3 hijos, Yolanda viaja a la ciudad de Lima donde compra verduras y ropa dependiendo de la demanda, la verdura lo vende en el mercado de abastos de la ciudad de Ayacucho y la ropa lo vende a crédito en su comunidad.

Mientras que Jossely es soltera y tiene 19 años, Jossely junto a su mamá tiene una tienda de abarrotes.

Alejandrina, Yolanda y Jossely necesitan préstamos de 900 soles, 900 soles, 1000 soles, dinero que será invertido en la compra de azúcar, fideo, leche, blusas, chompas, arroz y atún.

Los sueños de Alejandrina, Yolanda y Jossely son mejorar sus negocios, sus hijos sean profesionales y construir su casa.

Translated by Kiva volunteer, Emily Charnes

loans.use: TO PURCHASE STOCK FOR THEIR RESPECTIVE BUSINESSES SUCH AS SUGAR, NOODLES, MILK, RICE, TUNA AND MILK, AS WELL AS CLOTHING TO SELL.

loans.name: Marina's Group

texts.es:
Patrocinia, Marina and Marilia have been members of the communal bank of Chacco for 6 months, 1 year and 6 months respectively. They are from the community of Chacco which is located 30 minutes outside of the city of Ayacucho.

Patrocinia is 39 years old, and married with 4 children. She raises small animals to sell and also grows vegetables. Marina is 41 years and separated with 6 children. She sells baby chickens which she buys at various markets in the region. And Marilia is 20 years old and single. She sells drinks from a small shop she set up 6 months ago.

The women will use the loan to purchase stock for their respective businesses, including food for the animals, more chickens, sodas and drinks. Each of the women share the dream of growing their businesses and improving their homes.

Patrocinia, Marina y Marilia pertenecen al Banco Comunal Chacco hace 6 meses, 1 año, 6 meses respectivamente. Ellas son de la comunidad de Chacco que esta ubicado a 30 minutos de la ciudad de Ayacucho.

Patrocinia es casada, tiene 39 años y 4 hijos, Patrocinia se dedica a la crianza de animales y la agricultura de verduras.

Por otro lado Marina es separada, Marina tiene 41 años y 6 hijos, Marina vende pollos bebes, que compra de las granjas, en las diferentes ferias de la región.

Mientras que Marilia es soltera y tiene 20 años, Marilia tiene una tienda donde vende bebidas, actividad que inició hace 6 meses.

Patrocinia, Marina y Marilia necesitan préstamos de 600 soles, 900 soles, 1000 soles, dinero que será invertido en la compra de alimento para animales, pollo, cerveza y gaseosa.

Los sueños de Patrocinia, Marina y Marilia son mejorar sus negocios, tener una buena casa.

Translated by Kiva volunteer, Emily Charnes

loans.use: TO PURCHASE STOCK FOR THEIR RESPECTIVE BUSINESSES SUCH AS SODAS, DRINKS, CHICKENS AND FEED FOR THE ANIMALS.

payments.comment: Correction due to underpayment for business 46773

loans.name: Veronica

texts.es:
Mrs. Veronica M. lives in the neighborhood “22nd of January". She is 24 years old, married, and has no children. Her husband works as a cashier and provides for their daily expenses. She has been a teacher of primary school for the past 5 years. She is requesting a loan in order to build a new room in her home. In the future she would like to keep on studying so that she can become a professional worker and that way improve her family's quality of life.

Translated from Spanish by Samantha, Kiva volunteer.

La Sra. Verónica habita en el barrio 22 de enero es casada con 24 años de edad, no tiene aun hijos y su esposo es cajero. Quien aporta a los gastos de su hogar Ella es docente de primaria tiene cinco años de impartir clases. Con el préstamo que le van a prestar lo quiere invertir en la construcción de un cuarto, a futuro quiere seguir estudiando para ser una profesional y así mejorar su status de vida para su familia.

loans.use: To improve her house.

payments.comment: scheduled_repayment (late autopay posting for AFODENIC - Oct 25, 2008)

loans.name: Silvia Veronica

texts.es:
I have a dry goods and stationary store in which I provide people with services making photocopies, assembling documents, credentials and badges along with other services. I have the team I need to complete these tasks and for this reason I am asking for a loan of $700. This way I will be able give my customers better service in terms of what they need.

Translated from Spanish by a Kiva volunteer.

Cuento con un negocio de mercería y papelería en la que brindo a la gente el apoyo en cuestión de sacado de copias, engargolar documentos, engargolado de credenciales o gafetes, entre otros servicios; cuento con el equipo necesario para llevar a cabo dichas actividades, es por ello que pido el préstamo de la cantidad de $700.00 dlls. Para dar a las personas una mejor atención en cuanto a las necesidades que los mismos requieran.

loans.use: To stock my business

loans.name: Apolinar

texts.es:
I still need one more room for my house because my family is pretty big and we are crowded in the house and I would like my children to have a room. I need the materials to build the room. I am asking for a loan of $800 to build a room.

Translated from Spanish by a Kiva volunteer.

Me esta haciendo falta un cuarto extra en la casa ya que somos una familia algo grande y estamos muy reducidos en la casa me gustaría que los niño tuvieran su cuarto. Pero me esta haciendo falta material. Solcito un préstamo de $800.00 dlls para la construcción de un cuarto.

loans.use: Expand the bottom floor of my house.

loans.name: Rolando

texts.es:
I have almost finished building my house but I still need the exterior finishings to finish the work but I don't have the money immediately available. I am asking for a loan of $1,2000 to install the remaining finishings on the exterior of my house.
Translated from Spanish by a Kiva volunteer.
Ya casi termino de construir mi casa pero me esta haciendo falta los acabados de exterior para ya verla terminado pero no tengo el dinero de inmediato. Solicito un préstamo de $1,200.00 dlls para la terminación de los acabos del exterior de la casa.

loans.use: Finishings for the exterior of my house

payments.comment: correction due to overpayment for business 46777

loans.name: Leticia

texts.es:
Ms. Toscana has a small and cozy house but wants to improve her flooring and interior finishings. She needs a loan to buy floor tiles and to improve the appearance of her home. Her project will cost approximately $1,000. To improve her home and thus have a better place to live.

Translated from Spanish by a Kiva volunteer.

La Señora T. cuenta con una vivienda económica y comida pero desea mejorar los pisos de su casa al igual que los acabados interiores .Ella necesita un préstamo para comprar vitropisó y dar una apariencia mejor a su vivienda. Su proyecto cuesta aproximadamente $1,000 dlls. Para mejorar su vivienda y así tener un mejor lugar donde vivir.

loans.use: Floor tiles and finishing for the interior of the house

loans.name: Rosalinda

texts.es:
My house lacks a ceramic tile floor. I want to cover the children’s room more so that they will be more comfortable in their place. I request a loan of $1200 in order to lay ceramic tile florring inside the house and make it more comfortable.

Translated from Spanish by B, Kiva Volunteer.

En mi casa me esta haciendo falta el vitropiso. Quiero cubrir mas el cuarto de los niños y que ellos este mas cómodo en su lugar. Solicito un préstamo de $ 1,200.00 dlls. Para lo colocación del vitropiso dentro de la casa. Y así tener más comodidad en la vivienda

loans.use: To install a ceramic floor inside the house.

payments.comment: scheduled_repayment (late autopay posting for Fundación para la Vivienda Progresiva (FVP), a partner of CHF International - Oct 25, 2008)
correction due to overpayment for business 46779

loans.name: Sol Naciente Group

texts.es:
Every day in the market located in the “16 de Julio” community and in the neighboring kiosks, a variety of breakfasts, delicious lunches and other refreshments are offered by the majority of the members of the “Sol Naciente” Association. Preparation of the food obligates this group to remain in their stands for the entire day. That means working next to their small children, because they don’t make enough money to leave them in daycare centers, an unfortunate situation that leaves the children exposed to many dangers.

The “Sol Naciente” Association has worked with the Pro-Mujer organization for three years and, with the help of their loan advisor, has proven to be very well organized. They now need additional funds to be able to inject more capital into their businesses and thereby increase their income which will benefit their families.

Translated from Spanish by Hugh Yarbrough, Kiva Volunteer.

Todos los días en el mercado de la zona 16 de julio y kioscos aledaños al lugar, se ofrece variados desayunos, deliciosos almuerzos y otras meriendas. Actividad que se dedica la mayor parte de la asociación “Sol Naciente” La elaboración de estos alimentos obliga a este grupo a permanecer en sus puestos de venta por todo el día teniendo así que trabajar junto a sus pequeños hijos, ya que no cuentan con el dinero suficiente para poder dejarlos en guarderías, caso muy lamentable ya que los niños se ven expuestos a muchos peligros. La asociación Sol Naciente ya trabaja con la familia de Pro-Mujer hace mas de tres años con la ayuda de su asesor de creditos demuestran ser un grupo muy bien organizado. Ellas ahora precisan mayores créditos para poder inyectar capital a sus negocios de esta manera mejorar sus ingresos para el bien de sus familias.

loans.use: Additional funds will be invested in their food businesses

loans.name: Mildret

texts.es:
My house is very unprotected. I would like to finish the protective wall and cover it with stucco. This is more than anything for the security of my family since my husband and I work almost all day and the house is left alone. I request a loan of 1200 in order to raise the protective wall and cover it.

Translated from Spanish by B, Kiva Volunteer.

Mi casa esta muy desprotegida me gustaría terminar ya la barda y la losa. Esto es más que nada por la seguridad de mi familia ya que mi esposo y yo trabajamos casi todo el día y la casa esta sola. Solicito un préstamo de $1.200.00 Dlls. Para levantar la barda y colocación de la losa.

loans.use: To build a protective wall for more security and cover it.

payments.comment: scheduled_repayment (late autopay posting for Fundación para la Vivienda Progresiva (FVP), a partner of CHF International - Oct 24, 2008)
correction due to overpayment for business 46781

loans.name: Gregorio

texts.es:
I have time to work on my house but I lack the stucco to finish it. In order to have a place to live I am paying rent, which is making it difficult to finish the construction and pay the rent. I request a loan of $1000 in order to install the stucco and in this way bring my family to live in a more secure place of our own.

Translated from Spanish by B, Kiva Volunteer.

Tengo tiempo que empecé a construir mi casa pero me esta haciendo falta la losa para ya tenerla terminada. Y podernos ir a vivir hay como estoy pagando renta séme esta haciendo muy difícil terminar la construcción y pagar renta. Solicito un préstamo de $1,000.00 dlls. Para la colocación de la losa y así llevar a mi familia a vivir a un lugar mas seguro y de ellos mismos

loans.use: To stucco the house.

loans.name: Lorenzo

texts.es:
I have already almost finished building my house. All that it lacks is the concrete floor, painting and the stucco for the whole house. I request a loan of $1200 in order to finish my house so that my family will have a larger and more secure place to live.

Translated from Spanish by B, Kiva Volunteer.

Ya casi termino de construir mi vivienda solo que me esta haciendo falta el piso de concreto, pintura y los enjares en toda la casa. Solicito un préstamo de $ 1,200.00 dlls para la terminación de mi casa y que mi familia ya tengo un lugar mas amplio y seguro donde vivir.

loans.use: To lay the concrete floor, paint and stucco the house.

payments.comment: scheduled_repayment (late autopay posting for Fundación para la Vivienda Progresiva (FVP), a partner of CHF International - Oct 25, 2008)

loans.name: Mauricia

texts.es:
I need to put a protective wall around my house since there is no protection for my family and my husband works at night. We request a loan of $1000 in order to build a protective wall and floor on the front patio.

Translated from Spanish by B, Kiva Volunteer.

Necesito poner las bardas de mi casa ya que no tiene nada de seguridad para mi familia y mi esposo trabajo de noche. Solicitamos un préstamo de $1,000.00 dlls para la elaboración de las bardas y piso en el patio de enfrente.

loans.use: To build a protective wall around the house.

loans.name: Luís Antonio

texts.es:
I have a plot of land where I want to start to build my house, but I lack the materials and, as I am paying rent, I can not build and pay rent at the same time. I request a loan of $1200 in order to start to build a house.

Translated from Spanish by B, Kiva Volunteer.

Tengo un terrero el cual quiero empezar a construir mi casa pero me esta haciendo falta material y como estoy pagando renta no puedo construir y pagar renta al mismo tiempo. Solicito un préstamo de $ 1,200.00 dlls. Para en pesar la construcción de una casa.

loans.use: To begin to build a house.

loans.name: Juan Carlos

texts.es:
My home is not weatherproofed and with the hot season already starting it's becoming very hot inside for my children. I'm requesting a loan of $1,2000 for the weatherproofing and making the home cooler in the heat.
Translated from Spanish by Marty Greenstein, Kiva Volunteer
A mi casa le esta haciendo falta la impermeabilización ya que empieza la temporada de calor y las casa se pone muy caliente para los niños. Solicito un préstamo $1,200.00 dlls.Para la impermeabilización de la casa y así esta más fresca la casa  ahora en calor.

loans.use: Weatherproof home / Impermeabilizar la losa de una casa

payments.comment: scheduled_repayment (late autopay posting for Fundación para la Vivienda Progresiva (FVP), a partner of CHF International - Oct 23, 2008)
Over-reported by partner.  Reduced to local price.

loans.name: Sopharith

texts.en:
Mr. Sopharith S. lives in Angk Village in Kandal Province, Cambodia. He is 28 years old and is married to Mrs. Sokheourn Tith, who works in a garment factory. They do not have any children and they live with their parents.

Mr. Sopharith S. is a farmer and pig breeder in the village. He usually hires a worker to cultivate his rice plantation. Last year, he got a loan from Brasac Co., Ltd. to pay for hiring a worker, but insects destroyed his rice. Now that the rainy season is arriving, and Mr. Sopharith S. starts to cultivate rice, he needs to hire workers to work on the field. Therefore, he has asked for a loan to pay for the workers. He will also use the loan to buy more insecticides to help increase rice productivity.

loans.use: To pay for the workers and buy insecticides.

payments.comment: Mr. Sopharith Sam has paid off his loan 13 months in advance!! AMK and Kiva would like to thank you for lending to him and we hope you lend again soon! We\'ll do a journal on him very soon!

loans.name: Pong

texts.en: Mrs. Pong C. is 35 years old and earns about $2 per day sewing from her house. Her husband, Mr. Thorng Sophal, is a 38-year-old electrician and earns around $2 per day. They live with two children in Deumchan Village, Phnom Penh City. Now C. is seeking a loan of $500 to purchase one new sewing machine and to buy groceries to sell in front of her house. This loan helps to improve her family’s income so she can sufficiently support study fees for her children.

loans.use: To purchase one new sewing machine and to buy groceries to sell in front of her house

loans.name: Makulata

texts.en:
Makulata left school early and never finished her education. She is single and currently unemployed. She's responsible for looking after her grandparents at home and she chose to join our program and use her spare time for her ice-cake (ice cream) and pancake business so that she can get some money for her personal needs.

Makulata's loan will be used to buy ingredients like baking powder, sugar and flour needed for her business. She sells her pancakes on the weekends and the ice-cakes during the whole week. She feels so happy running her little business and thankful for the help she got from our program. Without it, she can't earn enough money for her personal needs but also those of her family. She wishes to stay for a long time in the SPBD program in order to get some betterment of her future life.

loans.use: Purchase ingredients for her pancake and ice-cake business

loans.name: Ping Pong I Village Bank Group

texts.en:
The Ping Pong I Village Bank consists of forty-one members.

Mrs. Yin S. is the Village Bank president. She is 49 years old and is a subsistence farmer who cultivates the field next to the village. She is the mother of three children. One works in a garment factory, another is working on the field with his parents, and the youngest is enrolled in state school.

The famiL. sometimes hires workers to work on their rice plantation, especialL. to plow, since they do not have enough draft animals. Last year, Mrs. Yin S. obtained a loan from Acleda Bank to hire a worker to plow the rice field, but insects destroyed her rice. Now, the monsoon season is coming soon, so it is time to cultivate rice, but Mrs. Yin S. does not have enough money to hire a worker.

Therefore, she is requesting a loan to hire a worker who has a draft animal to plow the rice field, and to buy insecticides to avoid last year’s problems.

loans.use: To hire a worker to plow the rice field, and to buy insecticides to save her crops

loans.name: Safua Siolo

texts.en:
Safua is a married mother of seven children. She is a very hard-working woman in her family. She performs various tasks that she knows she can earn money from, and one of them is her canteen business. She sells her goods at the village school and in her village too.

With her first loan, she bought ingredients and materials needed for running her fast foods stall business. The profits from her business support the financing of her children’s school fees and her other family daily needs.

The SPBD loan is her only available source of capital. She augments her income by also selling vegetables from time to time. She plans a long relationship with SPBD.

loans.use: Buy ingredients and goods for her fast food stall

loans.name: Laveainia

texts.en: Laveaina is a married mother with two children. She has been in our program for two years now.  Her first loan was for US$ 300 but her loan request has now increased to US$ 425. She said that both loans she got from this program helped the most in buying tools and chemicals such as the chromoxomes, weed killer, and fertilizer for the good growth of her plantation. And she believes without them, then she can not continue to improve her business which is her only source of income. Her husband also is very happy to work and plant more in the plantation using the tools they can get from these loans. She hopes to continue in the future and get more loans from this program where her next ambition is building a new house for the family.

loans.use: Buy tools and chemicals for her taro plantation

loans.name: Hadija's Umoja Group

texts.en:
Hadija is 45-years-old and is married with two children, ages 28 and 25. Hadija is a tailor and also sells snacks. she began her businesses in 2001. Hadija earns a monthly profit of approximately $40.

She is requesting a loan to purchase additional tailoring items and wheat flour for her business. She will share this loan with her group members, Mwatima, Zainabu,Pili, Zainab, and Zakia, who have businesses dealing in firewood, fish, mayai, snacks, juice and charcoal sales.

loans.use: To purchase tailoring items and  wheat flour

payments.comment: scheduled_repayment (late autopay posting for BRAC Tanzania - Oct 22, 2008)

loans.name: Kuwet A 2041-1 Group

texts.en:
The group leader of this small group is Sunday R.. She has a grocery and is requesting a loan to expand the business. Sunday is 30 years old and is married with a husband who is a peasant. She has 6 children and they go to school. Each week, Sunday makes approximately 200 Sudanese pounds in profits. With the extra profits from her loan, she hopes to be able to expand the business.

Sunday is joined in her small group by Orufa J., Teresa J., Alice K., and Mary K.. Orufa J. has grocery business and wants to pay the school fees for her children. Teresa J. is currently operating a business selling phoso and wants a loan for construction. Alice K. operates a bread business and wants to expand the business. Mary K. has a retail business and is requesting a loan to open up a shop.

loans.use: Expand her business

loans.name: Kuwet A 2041-1 Group

texts.en: The group leader of this small group is Sunday R..  she is currently in the business of grocery and is requesting a loan to expand the business.  Sunday is 30 years old and is married with a husband who is  a peasant .  she has 6 children ranging from age 6 to 20 and her children go to school.  each week, Sunday makes approximately 200sudanese pounds in profits and with the extra profits from her loan, she hopes to be able to expand the business. Sunday is joined in her small group by Orufa J., Teresa J., Alice K., and Mary K..  Orufa J. has a business in grocery and wants to pay the  school fees.  Teresa J. is currently operating a business in selling phoso and wants a loan for constraction.  Alice K. operates a business of sellng breads and wants to expand the business.  Mary K. is currently in the business of sellng at the shop and is requesting a loan to open up shop.

loans.use: expand the business

loans.name: Ada's Group

texts.en:
Ada T., age 34, is single with one 5-year-old child. She has an eggs business and nursery school which she began three years ago. Working from 8 a.m. to 5 p.m. daily, she is able to make a monthly profit of around $98.

Ada has taken out two previous loans from Tujijenge Tanzania to buy land, and now hopes for a new loan to increase capital. Ada will share this loan with her subgroup members who sell clothes, charcoal and food.

In the picture, Ada is first on the left front row

loans.use: To buy more eggs and make improvements to the nursery school.

loans.name: Rehema's Umoja Group

texts.en:
Rehema is 33- years-old and is divorced with two children, ages 6 and 2. In 2007, she opened her business selling fish and snacks. Rehema works from 8AM to 11PM each day and earns a monthly profit of approximately $35.

She is requesting a loan to purchase fish, cooking oil and flour for her business. She will share this loan with her group members Nyachia, Mapunda and Mwanahija, who have businesses selling charcoal, firewood, clothes and perfumes.

loans.use: To purchase fish, cooking oil and flour

loans.name: Wahida

texts.en:
Wahida is 25-years-old and is married with two children, ages 1 and 5. Wahida has been selling clothes (bedsheets and khanga--traditional sarongs) since 2001. She works five hours a day and earns a monthly profit of $50.

She is requesting a loan to buy additional bedsheets and khanga for her business.

loans.use: To purchase additional bedsheets and khanga for resale

loans.name: Halima

texts.en:
Halima A. runs a small street cafe in Zanzibar. Halima began her business in 1998 and runs the business each day from 7 AM to 10 PM. Her monthly profit is approximately $285.

She is 39-years-old and is married with five children, ranging from 14 to 21-years-old.

Halima is requesting a loan to purchase more food products for her cafe. She is a member of the loan group Usimtupe, whose members guarantee one another in paying back their loans.

loans.use: To buy more food products for resale

loans.name: Salama

texts.en:
Salama is 28-years-old and is married with three children; ages 6, 4 and 1. Salama sells clothes (bedsheets), which she began in 2003. She works six hours a day and can earn a monthly profit of about $90.

Salama is requesting a loan to purchase more clothes for her business.

loans.use: To purchase more clothes for resale

loans.name: Mwanakheri's Wanawake Svaendeleo Group

texts.en:
Mwanakheri J. A. is the leader of this group and has earned an income by selling charcoal and tailoring clothes since 2001. She is 34-years-old and is married with two children; ages three and seven. Her monthly profit is about $90.

She is requesting a loan to purchase more charcoal and sewing materials. Mwanakheri is joined in this subgroup by Fatma, Masemda, and Riziki. These members guarantee each other in paying back their loans.

loans.use: To purchase more sewing materials and charcoal

payments.comment: scheduled_repayment (late autopay posting for BRAC Tanzania - Oct 22, 2008)

loans.name: Khadija's Kitumawacho Hudumu Group

texts.en:
Khadija is a member of this subgroup and earns income by selling clothing. She is 42-years-old and married with three children ranging in age from 10 to 21.

Khadija is open for business each day from 7 AM to 10 PM making a monthly profit of $420. She is requesting a loan to purchase more clothing for resale. Khadija is joined in this subgroup by Asha and Neema. They belong to a loan group whose members guarantee one another in paying back their loans.

loans.use: To purchase clothing for resale

payments.comment: scheduled_repayment (late autopay posting for BRAC Tanzania - Oct 24, 2008)

loans.name: Twalha

texts.en:
Twalha is 31-years-old and is divorced with two children; ages 14 and 12. Twalha has been selling fish and soup since 2007. She works from 7AM to 10PM and can earn a monthly profit of about $160.

She would like to secure a loan to purchase more fish and meat for resale.

loans.use: To purchase more fish and meat for resale

loans.name: Mwanajuma

texts.en:
Mwanajuma is a widow with four children ages 14 (twins), 16, and 25. She makes a living as a dress maker and works from 8 AM to 4 PM daily. From this business, which she started ten years ago, she is able to make a monthly profit of about $85.

Mwanajuma hopes for a loan to purchase sewing materials in order to expand her business. She is a member of loan group Tuwtmaelto, whose members guarantee one another in paying back their loans.

loans.use: To purchase sewing materials

loans.name: Zena's Tuaminiane Group

texts.en:
Zena is 30-years-old and is married with 2 children, ages 6 and 4. Zena has been selling soup and perfumes since 2005. She works about seven hours each day at her business and can earn a monthly profit of $40.

She now hopes for a loan to purchase more meat for making her soups, and perfumes for her business. She will share this loan with her subgroup members; Ziada, Rahma, Nyafu, Bimkubwa and Fatma, who have businesses dealing in snacks, drawings and clothing sales.

loans.use: To purchase additional meat and perfume for resale

payments.comment: scheduled_repayment (late autopay posting for BRAC Tanzania - Oct 26, 2008)

loans.name: Saada

texts.en:
Saada is married with four children; ages 6, 17, 19, and 20. She started a small shop a year ago, where she sells general items. She works every day and is able to make a monthly profit of about $145 from this business.

Saada hopes for a loan to purchase more inventory for her shop. She is a member of loan group Subira Yavuta, whose members guarantee one another in paying back their loans.

loans.use: To buy more inventory for her shop

loans.name: Kea

texts.en:
Mr. Kea C. lives in Sre Au Village in Kampong Speu Province, Cambodia. He is 25 and is a farmer as well as a pig breeder. He is married with one child who is too young to work or study. His wife, Sreynich Tun, is a palm sugar maker in the local village. They both are hard workers and try to earn money to support their living expenses and the ones of their families.

To improve their living conditions, they want to start a new business. Consequently Mr. Kea C. would like to ask for a loan to buy a motorcycle with a cart to transport coal to Phnom Penh, the capital of Cambodia, where he can sell the coal for a higher price. ( His wife is also in the picture with him).

loans.use: To buy a motorcycle with a cart to transport coal.

loans.name: Atte Godfrey

texts.en:
Atte Godfrey was born in 1961. He is married and has one child. He lost his father when he was still in primary school, and he couldn't continue his education because his mother was unemployed. Things became very difficult for him when thieves broke into his house and stole his saw mill, which was the only source of income. Sickness also contributed to his decline. Motivated by all these circumstances, he became a member of GHAPE in 1999. Since then, he has successfully and repaid six loans totaling $680.

Given a loan, he plans to invest it in the cultivation of plantain and palms, and in poultry and pig farming. People in his community are going to benefit in the sense that he is going to provide jobs for the community. With the profits, he is going to educate his only child and also take care of his hospital bills.

He plans to repay the loan in 24 months. Repayment will begin on the fourth month from the date of disbursement.

loans.use: Plantain, palm, poultry, and pig farming

loans.name: Fotima

texts.ru:
Fotima G. lives in the Gissar region of Tajikistan. She is 20 years old and single. For the last six years Fotima has been making a living selling groceries in a small store close to her home. She brings goods from Dushanbe which she purchases from wholesalers. To increase the profits of her business and to attract new customers Fotima wants to expand the number of goods she offers for sale. To finance this she needs to take out a loan. She is planning to pay back the loan in the next 12 months.

Translated from Russian by Anya Lyuksyutova, Kiva volunteer

Гозиева Фотима жительница Гиссарского района . Ей 20 лет , она не замужем. Занимается торговлей продуктов питания. Имеет магазин рядом с домом. Привозит товар из города Душанбе , покупая у оптовых продавцов. Занимается этим видом бизнеса уже 6 лет. Хочет увеличить товарооборот. Для этого ей необходимо получить кредит. Погасить его она сможет в течении 12 месяцев. Если она увеличит ассортимент товара это поможет ей привлечь новых клиентов и принести дополнительный доход.

loans.use: Expanding inventory

payments.comment: scheduled_repayment (late autopay posting for MLF HUMO - Oct 25, 2008)

loans.name: Vorn

texts.en:
Mrs. Vorn C. is 41 and lives in Sre Au Village in Kampong Speu Province, Cambodia. She is the mother of five children, two of whom work in a garment factory, while the others study in the local school. Her husband, Vin Suong, is a bed maker in the village.

Mrs. Vorn Nuon is a farmer and last year her rice field faced drought. In addition, her land was infertile. For these reasons, she decided to request a loan to buy a water pump to irrigate her rice field and to buy fertilizer to enrich the infertile field. Her husband is on the right of the photo.

loans.use: To buy a water pump and fertilizer

loans.name: Sharifa's Tuaminiane Group

texts.en:
Sharifa is 47-years-old and is married with three children, ages 16, 9 and 14. She and her husband also take care of a three-year-old child. Sharifa started her business of selling soap and snacks in 2007. She works every day, earning a monthly profit of approximately $30 from her sales.

Sharifa has taken out one successful loan to start her business. She now hopes for another to buy more soap for resale. She will share this loan with her subgroup members Awena and Mariam, who have businesses dealing in firewood, charcoal, juice and phone card sales.

loans.use: To buy more soap for resale.

loans.name: Abduraimjon

texts.ru:
Abduraimjon H. lives in the Rudaki region of Tajikistan. He is married and has six children. Abduraimjon owns a car which he uses for his taxi service business. He has been earning a living as a taxi driver for the last 30 years. However he needs to repair his car since it's frequent break downs interfere with his work. To be able to finance the repairs Abduraimjon want to take out this loan which he is planning to pay back in the next 10 months. He is the main bread winner for his family and so it is essential that his little taxi car works reliably and without interruptions.

Translated from Russian by Anya Lyuksyutova, Kiva volunteer

Хужакулов Абдураимжон проживает в районе Рудаки . Имеет машину , которую использует для такси. Зарабатывает этим на жизнь. Водит такси уже 30 лет. Но машину необходимо отремонтировать , так как частые поломки мешают работе. Для того , чтобы сделать ремонт Абдураимжон хочет получить кредит , который сможет погасить в течениии 10 месяцев. Он женат и имеет 6 детей. Единственным кормильцем в семье является сам, поэтому наладить бесперебойную работу автомобиля для него необходимо необходимо.

loans.use: Car repairs

payments.comment: scheduled_repayment (late autopay posting for MLF HUMO - Oct 26, 2008)

loans.name: Nassra's Umoja Group

texts.en:
Nassra is married and has two children (ages 6 and 3). She sells phone vouchers, a business she has had for a year. She is able to make about $180 a month from her sales.

Nassra has received a loan in the past to increase her inventory of phone voucher cards. Having paid this back successfully, she now hopes for a new loan for the same purpose. She is a member of loan group Umoja and will be sharing this loan with Sauda, Zaituni, Fatma, and Fauzia.

loans.use: To purchase additional phone voucher cards for resale

payments.comment: scheduled_repayment (late autopay posting for BRAC Tanzania - Oct 24, 2008)

loans.name: Mwansifu

texts.en:
Mwansifu is a widow with three children (ages 12, 10, and 8). She has been selling shoes for ten years, giving her a monthly profit of about $230.

Mwansifu has previously secured a loan and met the payback requirements. This new loan would be used to purchase additional shoes for resale. She is a member of loan group W/na Maznelidu, whose members guarantee one another in paying back their loans.

loans.use: To purchase shoes for resale.

loans.name: Hostensia

texts.en:
Hostensia S. is single mother with four children. Faced with the challenges of being a single mother, she found it difficult to take care of her children, especially paying for schooling. In addition she sustained a serious accident, which placed her in abject poverty. Because of her lack of education she could not secure a good job for herself and she decided to try her hand at farming. Unfortunately, she didn't know how to improve on traditional farming techniques before coming to GHAPE.

After joining GHAPE, she learned farming techniques which have helped her improve yield. She has a successful history with previous loans, which she managed successfully and repaid in full.

Given a new loan, she plans to continue to invest in farming and embark on two new ventures: selling shoes and running a drug store. These activities are going to help her community, which needs a reliable supply of food, footware, and medication.

She plans to repay the loan in 24 months. The first installment is due on the fourth month from the date of disbursement.

loans.use: Purchase of farm equpment, shoes, and medicine

loans.name: Gulom

texts.ru:
Gulom G. lives in the Rudaki region of Tajikistan. He sells fruits and vegetables for a living. Since the Rudaki region is close to Dushanbe, capital of Tajikistan, Gulom can make a good profit by bringing the produce from faraway regions where it can be purchased for a low price. He then sells the produce at Dushanbe markets. Gulom wants to take out this loan to expand the amount of goods he is able to offer at his market stall. He is planning to pay back the loan in the next 10 months. Gulom lives with his young wife and parents and is the main bread winner for the family. Expanding his business will improve the quality of life for his entire family.

Translated from Russian by Anya Lyuksyutova, Kiva volunteer

Гафуров Гулом житель района Рудаки. Занимается торговлей овощей и фруктов. Район Рудаки находится рядом с городом Душанбе поэтому он привозит товар из дальных районов , где покупает по низким ценам у дехкан. А продает на рынке города Душанбе. Хочет увеличить товарооборот путем получения кредита. Погасить его сможет в течении 10 месяцев.Гулом живет со своей молодой женой и сродителями и является основным кормильцем семьи, поэтому увеличив товарооборот он увеличит доход своей семьи.

loans.use: Expanding inventory

loans.name: Fatma's Umoja Group

texts.en:
Fatma is 27 years old and is a married woman with 2 children, ages 6 and 1 year old. Fatma sells charcoal and juice. She started in 2005. Every day, she works from 7am to 5pm at her business and can earn a monthly profit of about $35 from her sales.

She now hopes for a loan to buy more charcoal and juice for her business. She will share this loan with her subgroup members, Ghanima, Mwanaid, Mwamvita, Salma, and Mawaharusi, who sell chips and snacks, run a cafe, and sell charcoal/firewood and clothing.

loans.use: To buy more charcoal and juice for her business.

loans.name: Rehema

texts.en:
Rehema M., age 30, is single with one 10-year-old child. She has a soft drinks business which she began a year ago. Working from 8 a.m. to 8 p.m. daily, she is able to make a monthly profit of about $17.

Rehema has taken out one previous loan from Tujijenge Tanzania to expand her soft drinks business. and now hopes for a new loan to buy and start selling beers and hard drinks as well as increase her stock of soft drinks.

loans.use: To begin the sale of  beer and hard drinks and increase stock for her soft drink business.

loans.name: Sharifa's Umoja Group

texts.en:
Sharifa is 46 years old and is a married woman with 6 children, ages 13-31 years old. Sharifa sells fish. She started in 2003. Every day, she works from 6am to 6pm at her business and can earn a monthly profit of about $70 from her sales.

She now hopes for a loan to buy more fish for her business. She will share this loan with her subgroup members, Khadiaj and Mwatum, who sell oil and fish.

loans.use: To buy more fish for her business.

loans.name: Fatma's Tubumisifu Nmissil Group

texts.en:
Fatma, age 45, is a widow who cares for her 3 children, ages 18, 16, and 8 years old. She makes a living selling charcoal and works from 7am to 10pm daily. From this business, which started 2 years ago, she is able to make a monthly profit of about $45.

Fatma hopes for a loan to purchase more charcoal to sell. She is a member of the Tubumisifu Nmillil loan group and will be sharing this loan with Mwamali, another group member. The members of this loan group guarantee one another in paying back their loans.

loans.use: To buy more charcoal to sell

loans.name: Fazilat

texts.ru:
Fazilat A. lives in the Rudaki region of Tajikistan. She has been baking cakes for sale for the last ten years. But she has three children and now Fazilat wants to open a cell phone center with one of her sons. They have a building in the center of their kishlak (mountain village) which needs to be equipped - a sign needs to be put up and tables and chairs purchased. To finance this Fazilat wants to take out this loan. She is confident that this new business will make a profit and as well as allow the locals to purchase phone cards to refill their wireless phone accounts. She is planning to pay back the loan in the next 12 months.

Translated from Russian by Anya Lyuksyutova, Kiva volunteer

Ахмедова Фазилат жительница района Рудаки. Занимается выпечкой тортов на продажу. Занимается этим уже 10 лет. Но у нее 3 детей и с одним из сыновей она хочет открыть диллерский центр. У них есть помещение в центре их кишлака , которое нужно оборудовать. Необходимо сделать вывеску , купить стол и стулья. Для этого Фазилат решила получить кредит. Их новое дело поможет получить доход , а так же обеспечить население пластиковыми картами для пополнения баланса мобильных телефонов.Погасить кредит она сможет в течении 10 месяцев.

loans.use: Purchase of furniture

payments.comment: scheduled_repayment (late autopay posting for MLF HUMO - Oct 25, 2008)

loans.name: Salama's Tujieumishe Group

texts.en:
Salama, age 50, is a widow who cares for her three children, ages 4, 3 and 2. She makes a living selling charcoal and works from 7am to 9pm daily. From this business, which started 5 years ago, she is able to make a monthly profit of about $45.

Salama hopes for a loan to purchase more charcoal to sell. She is a member of the Tujieumishe loan group and will be sharing this loan with Chsum, another group member. The members of this loan group guarantee one another in paying back their loans.

loans.use: To buy more charcoal to sell

loans.name: Robiya

texts.ru:
Robiya S. is a businesswoman who sells clothing. She has been managing a market stall at the central market in Fayzabad for the last six years. Robiya brings clothing from Dushanbe. Her business is doing well but she has a very large family and what she earns is often not enough to support them. Robiya is already 47 years old and she has four children. All of her children are attending school and to be able to give the best education to all of them Robiya has to work a lot. But she is not one to give up and currently she wants to take out a loan to expand her business. She is planing to pay back the loan int he next 12 months.

Translated from Russian by Anya Lyuksyutova, Kiva volunteer

Саъдуллоева Робия бизнесмен.Занимается торговлей одежды. Имеет торговую точку на центральном рынке Файзабада. Занимается этим уже 6 лет. Привозит товар из города Душанбе. Получает неплохой доход , но для ее большой семьи не хватает , того что она зарабатывает. Ей 47 лет и у нее 4 детей. Все дети учатся в школе , а для того чтобы дать образование детям, Робия должна много работать. Но она не унывает и теперь планирует получить кредит , погасить который сможет в течении 12 месяцев. На планируемый кредит она хочет увеличить товарооборот.

loans.use: Expanding inventory

loans.name: Amina's Jangombe00 Group

texts.en:
Amina is a widow who cares for her two children, ages 9 and 4. She makes a living selling charcoal and works from 7am to 4pm daily. From this business, which started 12 years ago, she is able to make a monthly profit of about $55.

Amina hopes for a loan to purchase more charcoal to sell. She is a member of the Jangombe00 loan group, and will be sharing this loan with H., another group member. The members of this loan group guarantee one another in paying back their loans.

loans.use: To buy more charcoal to sell

loans.name: Mauwa's Furaha Group

texts.en:
Mauwa is 48 years old and is a married woman with 11 children, ages 4-25 years old. Mauwa sells charcoal and bread. Everyday, she works from 6am to 8pm at her business and can earn a monthly profit of about $35 from her sales.

She now hopes for a loan to buy more charcoal for her business. She will share this loan with her subgroup members, Asya, Rabia and Zuhura, who sell charcoal and firewood, snacks, and clothing.

loans.use: To buy more charcoal for her business.

loans.name: Arafa

texts.en:
Arafa, age 20, is married with a toddler. She runs a charcoal and soup business, where she sells these items from 7am to 10pm daily. From this business, which started 6 months ago, she is able to make a monthly profit of about $110.

Arafa hopes for a loan to purchase more charcoal and more food ingredients for her business. She is a member of the Letu Moja loan group. The members of this loan group guarantee one another in paying back their loans.

loans.use: To buy more charcoal and food items

loans.name: Felicia

texts.en: Felicia O. is 52 years old. She is married and lives in Benin City, Edo State, Nigeria. She has a large family of 7 children. She sells plantains, Ogbone, peppers and yams. Felicia has been borrowing from LAPO for 3 years. She hopes for a loan of $600 to buy more plantains, Ogbone, peppers and yams. These food items are local delicacies in Nigeria. She expresses her gratitude to Kiva and its lenders.

loans.use: To buy more plantains, Ogbone, peppers and yams

loans.name: Rano

texts.ru:
Rano M. is a businesswoman. She lives in Dushanbe and owns a sales spot on a pedestrian street where she sells food, sambusa and drinks. She has been in this business for 4 years. Rano is 32 years old and is married. She lives in a large family, with her parents, her brother and his family. Rano’s business allows her to help her brother and her parents.

Rano will use this loan to purchase a frying pan to make hot dogs and to increase inventory. Rano will pay back the loan over a 10 month period.

Translated from Russian by Sabina Holzman, Kiva Volunteer.

Миранонова Рано- предприниматель.Живет в городе Душанбе. Имеет торговую точку на прохожей улице , где торгует продуктами питания и продает самбусу и напитки. Занимается этим уже 4 года. Ей 32 года , но она не замужем. Тем не менее она живет в большой семье , где живуут ее родители и брат со своей семьей. Своим делом она помогает брату и родителям. Сейчас она хочет получить кредит , чтобы купить сковородку для приготовления хот-догов и увеличить товарооборот. А погасить кредит она сможет в течении 10 месяцев.

loans.use: Purchase frying pan and increase inventory

loans.name: Zulfiya

texts.ru:
Zulfiya V. lives in Dushanbe. She is 31 years old and has a university education. Zulfiya is an economist by profession and works in the Statistics bureau. She will use the loan to remodel her apartment. Without the loan she will not be able to do the remodel. The remodel will improve the living conditions for Zulfiya and her two children. She will pay back the loan over a 10 month period.

Translated from Russian by Sabina Holzman, Kiva Volunteer.

Вахобова Зульфия живет в городе Душанбе. Возраст 31год. Образование высшее. По специальности экономист. Работает экономистом в Статистическом управлении. Хочет получить кредит для того, чтобы сделать ремонт квартиры. Для этого она хочет получить кредит , так как без дополнительных денег сделать ремонт она не сможет.Сделав ремонт она улучшит условия жизни себе и своим двум детям. Получив кредит она сможет погасить его в течении 10 месяцев.

loans.use: Remodel apartment

loans.name: Maryam

texts.en:
Maryam is married with 6 children, ages 26, 21, 11, 10, and 6. She sells juice, and started this business a year ago. From her sales, she makes about $170 a month, working from 7am to 9pm daily.

Maryam hopes for a loan to buy more juice ingredients in order to expand her business. She is a member of the Tusikose Yote loan group, whose members guarantee one another in paying back their loans.

loans.use: To buy more juice ingredients

loans.name: Fatuma

texts.en:
Fatuma is 30 years old and is a married woman with 2 children, ages 8 and 2 years old. Fatuma owns a small grocery store, which she started in 2006. Every day, she works from 8am to 5pm at her business and can earn a monthly profit of about $240 from her sales.

She now hopes for a loan to buy more food items for her business.

loans.use: To buy more food items for her business.

loans.name: Rose

texts.en:
Rose is married with a 3-year-old child. She works as a supplier delivering crafts, such as mats and drums, to various shops in her locality. She started this business 2 years ago and now makes about $85 a month from her work.

In the past, Rose has taken a loan to help increase her work in order to supply more crafts to more shops. She now hopes for a new loan for the same purpose.

She is a member of the Subira Yaritfa Heri loan group. The members of this loan group guarantee one another in paying back their loans.

loans.use: To expand her business of supplying crafts

loans.name: Halima's Kitunawacho Hudum Group

texts.en:
Halima, age 30, is married with a 3-year-old child. She runs a fruit and vegetable shop, where she also sells other food items. She started this business a year ago and works from 8am to 4pm daily. From this business, she is able to make a monthly profit of about $65.

Halima hopes for a loan to purchase more fruits and vegetables to sell. She will share this loan with Asha, Mwatima, Pili, and Fatma, who are also members of the Kitunawacho Hudum loan group. The members of this loan group guarantee one another in paying back their loans.

loans.use: To purchase more fruits and vegetables to sell

payments.comment: scheduled_repayment (late autopay posting for BRAC Tanzania - Oct 22, 2008)

loans.name: La

texts.en:
Mrs. La C. was born 1980 and lives in Trauk Leak Village in Kampong Speu Province, Cambodia. She is a subsistence farmer and the mother of three children, all of whom are attending school. Her husband, Lai Lonh, is also a farmer. They live independently from their parents. They are very hard workers and try to earn money to support their family.

In November 2007, their children got dengue fever and they spent $250 for their care. Also, last year, their rice field faced drought, making their crop smaller. As a result, Mrs. La C. does not have enough money to buy cows to plow the rice field this year. She decided to request a loan to buy cows to use as draft animals.

Her husband is on the left of the picture.

loans.use: To buy cows to plow their rice field

loans.name: Fatuma's Maua Women Group

texts.en:
Fatuma is 48 years old and is a married woman with 4 children, ages 38,28,26 and 24 years old. Fatuma owns a small salon. Every day, she works from 9am to 8pm at her business and can earn a monthly profit of about $400 from her sales.

She now hopes for a loan to buy more salon items for her business. She will share this loan with her subgroup members Neema, Fatuma, and Aisha, who sell charcoal and operate a cafe.

loans.use: To buy more salon items for her business.

loans.name: Hidaya's Maua Women Group

texts.en:
Hidaya is 32 years old and is a married woman with 3 children, ages 16, 5, and 3 years old. Hidaya owns a small general store, which she started in 2006. Every day, she works from 8am to 5pm at her business and can earn a monthly profit of about $190 from her sales.

She now hopes for a loan to buy more items for her store. She will share this loan with her subgroup members, Nuru, Aneth, Zuhura and Husina, who sell cosmetics, charcoal, and food, and have a tailor shop.

loans.use: To buy more items for her business.

loans.name: Alfoncina

texts.en:
Alfoncina is 48 years old and is a married woman with 4 children, ages 16-25 years old. Alfoncina is a tailor. She started in 2004. Every day, she works from 8am to 6pm at her business and can earn a monthly profit of about $240 from her sales.

She now hopes for a loan to buy more supplies for her tailoring business.

loans.use: To buy supplies for her tailoring business

loans.name: Asha

texts.en:
Asha, age 41, is married with 7 children, ages 22, 21, 20, 19, 18, and 17 years old. She owns a food business, in which she sells fish and other items. She works from 7am to 10pm daily. From this business, which she started 7 years ago, she is able to make a monthly profit of about $290.

In the past. Asha has taken a loan in order to increase her business. She successfully repaid this loan and now hopes for a new loan to purchase more fish and other food items. She is a member of the Ari Mpya loan group, whose members guarantee one another in paying back their loans.

loans.use: To buy more food items and fish

loans.name: Amina's Sayuni Group

texts.en:
Amina is 22 years old and is single. Amina owns a small beauty salon, which she started in 2004. Every day, she works from 8am to 8pm at her business and can earn a monthly profit of about $90 from her sales.

She now hopes for a loan to buy supplies for her business. She will share this loan with her subgroup members, Devotha, Serania, and Mwamshindo, who sell artwork and food.

loans.use: To buy more salon items for her business.

loans.name: Salma

texts.en:
Salma, age 22, is single and cares for her parents. She runs a food business and started a clothing business 5 months ago. Her new business has been doing well and she is now able to make a monthly profit of about $120 from her work.

Salma hopes for a loan to purchase more clothing and food items to sell. She is a member of the Karimu loan grou , whose members of this loan group guarantee one another in paying back their loans.

loans.use: To purchase more clothing and food items

loans.name: Mwatima's Kiwa Mama Bora Group

texts.en:
Mwatima, age 27, is the a single parent of 3 children. She owns a charcoal and bread business, and has been selling these items for 3 years. Each month, these sales bring her a profit of about $180.

Mwatima hopes for a loan to buy more charcoal and bread to sell. She will share this loan with Mwanajuma. They are both members of the Kiwa Mama Bora loan group, whose members guarantee one another in paying back their loans.

loans.use: To buy more charcoal and bread to sell

loans.name: Karoli's Group

texts.en:
Karoli J., age 34, single with one 8-year-old child, has a retail shop which he began three years ago. He works in his shop daily from 6:30 a.m. to 10:30 p.m. and is able to make a monthly profit of about $99.

In the past, Karoli has taken out two previous loans with Tujijenge Tanzania to increase his shop stock. He hopes for a new loan to go upcountry and buy big stocks of beans and rice. Karoli will share this loan with his subgroup members, who operate businesses in tailoring, selling charcoal, fruits, ties and dyes, bread, and telephone vouchers..

In the picture Karoli is the first on the left back row standing.

loans.use: To go upcountry and buy large stocks of beans and rice.

payments.comment: scheduled_repayment (late autopay posting for Tujijenge Tanzania Ltd - Oct 26, 2008)

loans.name: Hidaya

texts.en:
Hidaya, age 49, is a widow who cares for her three children, ages 11, 3 and 4. She makes a living by selling food at her small cafe. She works there from 7am to 4pm daily. From this business, which started 4 years ago, she is able to make a monthly profit of about $280.

Hidaya hopes for a loan to purchase more food items for her cafe. She is a member of the Tuwemato loan group. The members of this loan group guarantee one another in paying back their loans.

loans.use: To buy more food items for her small cafe

loans.name: Zehera

texts.en:
Zehera, age 27, is married with three children, ages 7, 6, and 3. She has a clothing business and sells clothes from 8am to 4pm daily. From this business, which started 2 years ago, she is able to make a monthly profit of about $60.

Zehera hopes for a loan to purchase more clothing to sell. She is a member of the Tupendani loan group. The members of this loan group guarantee one another in paying back their loans.

loans.use: To buy more clothing to sell

loans.name: Asha

texts.en:
Asha, age 50, is a single parent of 7 children. She makes a living by selling clothing and works from 8am to 4pm daily. Each month, her sales bring her a profit of about $85.

loans.name: Martha's Group

texts.en:
Martha B., age 40, is single with one child, who is 7 years old. She sells bricks and milk as well as animal feed, which she began two years ago. She works from 10am to 6pm daily and is able to make a monthly profit of about $160.

In the past , Martha has taken out two previous loans from Tujijenge Tanzania to start her animal feed business and increase her brick stock. She hopes for a new loan to start a vegetable and fruit stall and also to start a retail shop. Martha will share this loan with her subgroup members who have shops, salons, and vegetable and fruit businesses.

In the picture, Martha is the first person standing on the left.

loans.use: To start selling fruits/vegetables and open a retail shop

loans.name: Gulnaz's Group

texts.en:
Gulnaz A., the group leader, comes from Multan, a city famous for its shrines in Pakistan. She has lived all her life in this city. Guinaz was married seven years ago and is the mother of four: three daughters and one son. Two of her older children attend school and the others are not of school age yet. Gulnaz’s husband has a mobile phone Sims dealership. His monthly income ranges between $175 and $200.

Currently, Guinaz's family needs a loan to expand their business. Gulnaz has been joined in her loan group by five women: Rukhsana P. requires her share of the loan to expand her scarves business, Hanifa B. will invest her share in her family’s grocery store, Shahbaz S. sells oil, Sonia B. will buy a rickshaw, and Zahida F. sells cloth.

This is a group loan. The loan funds will be distributed among the group members, each of whom will invest in her own business. The members mutually guarantee one another's loans. If one member does not repay, the other members are responsible.

loans.use: To expand their businesses

loans.name: Jennifer

texts.en: Jennifer M. is from Kyela Mbeya, Tanzania.  She is 27 years old, married, and has one thee year old child. In 2007, Jennifer established a soap production business. She has already received and successfully repaid one loan from SELFINA, and now requires a new loan of $575 in order to buy additional soap ingredients facilities of production.

loans.use: To buy additional ingredients for soap production.

Kimwana hopes for a loan to purchase more beverages for her shop. She will share this loan with her subgroup, who are all members of Wima loan group. The members of this loan group guarentee one another in paying back their loans.

loans.use: To buy more alcohol and soft drinks to sell

loans.name: Festa

In 2008, Festa  established her own tailoring business with the help of Selfina, an organization that works towards the economic empowerment of women in Tanzania through sale and leaseback agreements.  Festa now requires a loan of $175 in order to buy more cloth for her boutique.

loans.use: To buy more cloth for the boutique.

loans.name: Shahnaz's Group

texts.en:
I am Shahnaz S. from Multan, a mid-sized city in Pakistan. I am married and the mother of five: three daughters and two sons. My eldest daughter is 15 years old and studies in grade eight; the next to her is 11 years old and attends grade six. Then comes my nine-year-old son who studies in grade four. The daughter next to him is seven years old and studies in class one, while the youngest of all is too young to attend school. My husband is a welder and manufactures objects such as iron window frames and doors and I sew clothes for my neighborhood clients on order. I need to buy computerized sewing machines so that I can hire a few girls and thereby expand my business.

There are four other women who are also in need of loans and they are: Naseem R., who requires a loan for her vegetable business; Koser P., who runs a boutique; Shamim S., who will buy a dairy cow; and Ayesha K., who runs a canteen in a school.

This is a group loan. The loan funds will be distributed among the group members, each of whom will invest in her own business. The members mutually guarantee one another's loans. If one member does not repay, the other members are responsible.

loans.use: To expand the group's businesses and improve living standards

Fatma hopes for a loan to purchase more food items in order to increase her stock. She is a member of loan group Wema and will be sharing this loan with her subgroup. The members of this loan group live in the same neighborhood and guarantee one another in paying back their loans.

She is now requires a loan of $425 in order to buy more rice in bulk.

loans.name: Amina's Group

texts.en:
Amina A. has lived all her life in Multan, a mid-sized city in Pakistan. She is married and the mother of two boys and one girl. Her husband has run a school canteen for the last four years and Amina helps him in this business. They are able to earn almost $100 to $150 a month.

Amina now wants to start an additional canteen in one of the local colleges and hence she is in need of a loan. Amina would like to borrow this loan in a group whose other members are: Zubaida B., who , wants to start an internet cafe; Saira B., who will buy an ice-cream machine; Nasreen B., who will buy a sewing machine; and Mamen N., who will invest her share of the loan in her husband’s vegetable business.

This is a group loan. The loan funds will be distributed among the group members, each of whom will invest in her own business. The members mutually guarantee one another's loans. If one member does not repay, the other members are responsible.

loans.use: To fund a school canteen and various other businesses

My husband works at a private institution in another city, Lahore, Pakistan, while I run a boutique. I started this boutique two years ago and currently I need to expand it.

I have been joined in my loan group by four other women who are: Tahira B., who is borrowing for her family’s fruits business; Zulaikha K. who makes flower bouquets; Samina N., who runs a boutique; and Fatima B., whose husband trades livestock.

This is a group loan. The loan funds will be distributed among the group members, each of whom will invest in her own business. The members mutually guarantee one another's loans. If one member does not repay, the other members are responsible.

Currently, Anweri and her husband have an income of $100 a month. They want to expand their pharmacy and Anweri hopes that their income will increase after this expansion and will let her build an additional storey on her house. Anweri is the leader of a group with three other women. Zareena B. runs a grocery store, Pakeeza B. has a fruit business, and Sajida B. sells cloth.

This is a group loan. The loan funds will be distributed among the group members, each of whom will invest in her own business. The members mutually guarantee one another's loans. If one member does not repay, the other members are responsible.

She now hopes for a loan to buy more food items for her business.

loans.use: To buy more food items for her business.

loans.name: Bupe

texts.en:
Mambo from Dar es Salaam, Tanzania! This is 30-year-old Bupe M.. She is married and has 3 children aged 1, 5 and 13. In 2001, Bupe established her genge business. Bupe has already received and successfully repaid 1 loan from SELFINA and now requires a new loan in order to buy more stock in bulk. She thanks you for your support.

When you see a SELFINA entrepreneur whose business title is ‘restaurant’ or ‘café’, you may have to adjust your mental image of what that is. A local restaurant or café in Tanzania usually consists of a rough wooden table and some long, wooden benches, with the sky as a ceiling. Such places don’t even appear in the Lonely Planet’s budget guide, but if you’re looking for a cheap and tasty meal and someone to have a chat with, this is the place to be. The food is all-local; rice, ugali (a hot, icky dough, made from maize flour), a plantain (a cooked savoury banana), all served with beans, vegetables, meat, and a variety of yummy sauces.

loans.use: To buy more stock in bulk.

loans.name: Marcos

texts.es:
Mr. Marco Antonio is a popular tailor in his neighborhood. He learned the trade from his stepfather, Mr. Pedro Rodríguez, by working for many years as his assistant. Two years ago, Marco started his own workshop with his own machines and capital.

Marco has many satisfied clients, due to his good workmanship and punctuality. He makes many different types of clothes, such as pants, jackets, and work uniforms.

Marco is now hoping to use a loan to invest in fabrics, as well as other inputs like zippers, buttons, and thread. A loan will enable him to purchase these materials in larger quantities and thereby obtain a discount. This will allow Marco to improve his earnings.

Translated from Spanish by Sarah Bishop, Kiva Volunteer.

El señor Marco Antonio es un reconocido sastre de su barrio quien aprendió el oficio de su padrastro el señor Pedro Rodríguez con quien trabajo mucho tiempo como ayudante y hace dos años se independizo formando su propio taller con maquinas y capital propios.

Cuenta que posee muchos clientes que están muy satisfechos con su trabajo, ya que además de su buena confección es un señor muy responsable y puntual a la hora de entregar sus trabajos. Realiza distintos tipos de confecciones como pantalones, sacos y uniformes para oficinas.

Hoy día Marcos está pensando invertir el crédito en la compra de telas al por mayor así como también otros insumo como cierres, botones, hilos entre otros pues al comprar al contado y en grandes cantidades obtiene buenos descuentos que le permiten incrementar sus ganancias.

loans.use: Purchase of fabric, zippers, buttons, and thread.

loans.name: Habiba's Tuko Imara Group

texts.en:
Habiba, is divorced and takes care of her four children (ages 25, 22, 18, and 20). She makes a living by tailoring dresses and selling chickens. She works from 8am to 4pm daily at these businesses. She is able to make a monthly profit of about $85 from her work.

Habiba hopes for a loan to purchase more dress materials and more chickens. She will share this loan with her subgroup, who are part of loan group Tuko Imara. The members of this loan group guarantee one another in paying back their loans.

loans.use: To buy more dress materials and chickens

payments.comment: scheduled_repayment (late autopay posting for BRAC Tanzania - Oct 22, 2008)

loans.name: Elizabeth

texts.en:
Elizabeth is a single woman. Elizabeth owns a small cafe, which she started in 2001. Everyday, she works from 7am to 9pm and can earn a monthly profit of about $250 from her sales.

She now hopes for a loan to buy more items for her cafe.

loans.use: To buy more items for her cafe.

loans.name: Abeda's Tujibe Moyo Group

texts.en:
Abeda, age 30, is married with three children (ages 14, 13, and 11). She owns a small cafe and works there from 8am to 7pm daily. From this business, which started 5 years ago, she is able to make a monthly profit of about $50.

Abeda hopes for a loan to purchase more food items for her cafe. She will share this loan with her subgroup, fellow members of the loan group Tujibe Moyo. The members of this loan group guarantee one another in paying back their loans.

loans.use: To buy food items for her cafe

loans.name: Mariam

texts.en:
Mambo from Kyela Mbeya, Tanzania! This is 35-year-old Mariam M.. She is married and has 3 children aged 2, 7 and 15. She has 4 more dependents who live with her because they are street children. In 1996, Mariam established her café business. She now requires a loan in order to buy more kitchen utensils. She thanks you for your support.

When you see a SELFINA entrepreneur whose business title is ‘restaurant’ or ‘café’, you may have to adjust your mental image of what that is. A local restaurant or café in Tanzania usually consists of a rough wooden table and some long, wooden benches, with the sky as a ceiling. Such places don’t even appear in the Lonely Planet’s budget guide, but if you’re looking for a cheap and tasty meal and someone to have a chat with, this is the place to be. The food is all-local; rice, ugali (a hot, sticky dough, made from maize flour), a plantain (a cooked savoury banana), all served with beans, vegetables, meat, and a variety of yummy sauces.

loans.use: To buy more kitchen utensil.

loans.name: Recho

texts.en:
Mambo from Kyela Mbeya, Tanzania! This is 25-year-old Recho M.. She is not married and has 1 blessed child aged 3. She has 1 more dependent who lives with her because he is an orphan. In 2000, Recho established her used clothing business. She now requires a loan in order to buy more stock in bulk. She thanks you for your support.

Secondhand clothes journey across the oceans from America and Europe and are then washed, ironed and sold in bulk by wholesalers in Dar es Salaam to retailers who then rewash and re-iron them for sale on the streets of Dar es Salaam and the surrounding towns and villages. These clothes are becoming increasingly popular, especially among the younger generation, because they are so cheap and because of the general appeal of anything Western or modern. Many people argue that the popularity of the West’s cast-offs is damaging the local cloth and garment industry. There are many people who still appreciate the beauty of traditional Tanzanian dress, however, the growing market in used clothing and its importance to many micro-entrepreneurs cannot be denied.

loans.use: To buy more stock in bulk.

loans.name: Mwajuma's Tujibe Moyo Group

texts.en:
MwaJ. is divorced and takes care of her three children (ages 10, 7 and 5). She makes a living by selling food at her small cafe, where she works from 8 A.M. to 5 P.M. daily. From this business, which she started just 8 months ago, she makes a monthly profit of about $70.

MwaJ. hopes for a loan to purchase more food items for her cafe. She will share this loan with her subgroup, members of loan group Tujibe Moyo. The members of this loan group guarantee one another in paying back their loans. .

loans.use: To buy more food items for her cafe

loans.name: Sarah Namutebi's Group

texts.en:
Sarah is the leader of 5 members. She is 38 and married with 7 children. They are 18, 14, 12, 10, 8 (twins), and 5. All of them are in school. The community she lives and works in is semi urban and a slum within a low-lying area that floods in the rainy season.

Her main challenges are the high transport costs and the floods that make her place of work inaccessible to clients.

She rents an open space and uses part of her courtyard to display the eucalyptas poles. These poles are used in the construction of houses. There is an available market because the construction industry is booming everywhere in Uganda.

She is able to pay rent and school dues and contribute to the family welfare.

Her biggest plan is to buy a motor vehicle to help in the transportation of these poles from the villages to the distribution point.

Sarah has successfully paid back more than 15 loans.

loans.use: Her biggest plan is to buy a motor vehicle to help in the transportation of poles.

loans.name: Hasija

texts.en: Hasija Husić is from Maglaj and she lives there together with her husband. Her husband works and he is earning around 500 KM (about US$ 400). This is her first loan through MCO WWI  in the amount of US$ 975. Hasija will use this loan to buy new multi-purpose vacuum cleaner  for her household. She can earn additional money by cleaning furniture in other households.

loans.use: To buy new multi-purpose vacuum cleaner

loans.name: Ndigwaki

texts.en:
Mambo from Kyela Mbeya, Tanzania! This is 25-year-old Ndigwaki M.. She is married and has 1 child aged 5. She has 1 more dependent who lives with her because he is an orphan.
