Joshpen's boutique does well and therefore she has hired a few employees to help her. She has also displayed her work in various exhibitions and at her home. She has been in this profession for 13 years. She has a diploma related to her profession from a renowned college and is strong in her work. Through the earnings from this business she has been able to convert her one-storey house into a four-storey house. Now she wishes to train her employees in shoemaking and beautician courses. Joshpen needs this loan to expand her boutique business.

loans.use: Expand a boutique business

loans.name: Yin

texts.en: Mrs. Yin M. is 63 and she is a farmer in Makak Village in Kampong Speu Province. She is the mother of a child who is employed in a garment factory. She and her husband work as rice farmers. They are subsistence farmers, but they also sell some of their rice. Last year, Mrs. Yin M. obtained a loan from AMK to buy a cow for breeding. Now Mrs. Yin M. wants to request a new loan to improve her farm.

loans.use: To build a house for hosting her family and improve her life conditions.

loans.name: Shahida

texts.en: Shahida Baji, wife of Mr. T., has been married for 30 years. She has four daughters and one son. All are being educated at a local school near their residence. Shahida is a  housewife and her husband used to be  a Senior Assistant Clerk in a bank. Then her husband retired and took the “Golden Hand Shake” ( a type of award received upon voluntary retirement) from the government.   With the award money he bought three cars and started a car rental business. In addition, her husband also runs a Public Call Office (called a PCO) and a shop where he makes photocopies and binds books.  Shahida needs a loan to purchase a new photocopier and paper and toner for her husband’s shop.

loans.use: To expand a photocopy shop

payments.comment: scheduled_repayment (late autopay posting for Asasah, a partner of Save the Children - Oct 23, 2008)

loans.name: Edith

texts.en:
Mambo from Kyela Mbeya, Tanzania! This is 39-year-old Edith M.. She is not married and has 3 blessed children aged 5,10 and 15. She has 5 more dependents who live with her because they are orphans. In 2003, Edith established her genge business. She now requires a loan in order to buy more stock in bulk. She thanks you for your support.

When you see a SELFINA entrepreneur whose business title is ‘restaurant’ or ‘café’, you may have to adjust your mental image of what that is. A local restaurant or café in Tanzania usually consists of a rough wooden table and some long, wooden benches, with the sky as a ceiling. Such places don’t even appear in the Lonely Planet’s budget guide, but if you’re looking for a cheap and tasty meal and someone to have a chat with, this is the place to be. The food is all-local; rice, ugali (a hot, icky dough, made from maize flour), a plantain (a cooked savoury banana), all served with beans, vegetables, meat, and a variety of yummy sauces.

loans.use: To buy more stock ni bulk.

loans.name: Rehema

texts.en:
Mambo from Kyela Mbeya, Tanzania! This is 20-year-old Rehema M.. She is married and has 2 children aged 4 and 6. She has 2 dependents who live with her because they are street children. In 2007, Rehema established her soft drink business. She now requires a loan in order to buy more stock of soft drinks. She thanks you for your support.

It is said that Coca Cola is one of the most recognized symbols or ‘words’ in the world. And it’s true. Even in the most remote villages in Africa, there is usually some kind of bar selling Coke, Fanta, and Guinness (Pepsi has made it to most African capitals but not to the sticks, but I’m sure they’re working on it!). The hot weather makes soft drinks all the more appealing--a very cheap marketing tool! All of which explains why selling soft drinks is such a popular venture, whether you’re the CEO of Coca Cola in the United States or a micro-entrepreneur in Tanzania!

loans.use: To buy more stock of soft drinks

loans.name: Jamila's Uzuri Group

texts.en:
Jamila is a 45 year old married woman with 5 children, from 12 to 20 years old. Jamila is a fish seller, a business she started in 2005. Every day she works from 7 A.M. to 6 P.M., and she earns a monthly profit of about $225.

She now hopes for a loan to buy more fish for her business.

loans.use: To buy more fish for her business

loans.name: Catherine

texts.en:
Mambo from Kyela Mbeya, Tanzania! This is 37-year-old Catherine M.. She is married and has 4 children aged 3, 7, 10 and 13. She has 5 dependents who live with her because they are orphans. In 1999, Catherine established her cereal crop selling business. She now requires a loan in order to buy more stock of the crop in bulk. She thanks you for your support.

SELFINA is engaged in economic empowerment of women in Tanzania through leasing and leaseback facilitation as a practical way to achieve the economic and social emancipation of women.

SELFINA has taken a lead role as a pioneer of micro-credit in Tanzania through Micro-Leasing. Customs and traditions in Tanzania normally make it difficult for women to own land and assets, thus they are termed not-creditworthy by financial institutions as they lack tangible collateral assets. This leads to poor financial support, hence poor access to basic needs and services for women with low incomes.

SELFINA buys and leases equipment to women. Where a client needs working capital SELFINA buys equipment from said client, extending a loan to her, then leasing back the same equipment—a process called a sale and leaseback arrangement.

loans.use: To buy more stock of the crop in bulk.

loans.name: Tusekilege

texts.en:
Mambo from Kyela Mbeya, Tanzania! This is 46-year-old Tusekelege K.. She is a widow and has 5 children aged between 9 and 19. She has 1 more dependent who lives with her because he is disabled. In 2007, Tusekelege established her crops business. She now requires a loan in order to buy more stock of the crop in bulk. She thanks you for your support.

SELFINA is engaged in economic empowerment of women in Tanzania through leasing and leaseback facilitation as a practical way to achieve the economic and social emancipation of women.

loans.use: To buy more stock of the crop in bulk.

loans.name: Grace

texts.en:
Grace is a married woman with 2 children, ages 12 and 7. Grace sells clothing, a business she started in 2002. Every day she works from 7 A.M. to 7 P.M., and she earns a monthly profit of about $300.

She now hopes for a loan to buy more clothes for her business.

loans.use: To buy more clothes for her business.

loans.name: Safia's Wema Group

texts.en:
Safia is married with four children (ages 7, 11, 15, and 17). She runs a tailoring business where she sews dresses. From this business, which started 13 years ago, she makes a monthly profit of about $55.

Safia hopes for a loan to purchase more material for her business. She will share this loan with her subgroup, whose members belong to loan group Wema. These members guarantee one another in paying back their loans.

loans.use: To purchase more material for her tailoring business

payments.comment: scheduled_repayment (late autopay posting for BRAC Tanzania - Oct 25, 2008)

loans.name: Riffat

texts.en:
Riffat Bibi, wife of Mr. J. A., is married for one year and is the mother of a son. Before her marriage, Riffat worked in a beauty parlor. Riffat’s husband works at a renowned restaurant chain and he runs a garment shop to supplement his income. He has hired two salesmen for his garment stall and he currently purchases his garment inventory from a specific garment factory.

Riffat is in need of a loan to purchase stitching equipment so that she and her husband can themselves manufacture ready-made garments for their garment store. Riffat hopes to also start a beauty parlor in the near future so that she can help her husband and can share his financial burden .

loans.use: To manufacture the inventory for a garment business

loans.name: Loveness

texts.en:
Loveness is a married woman with 2 children, ages 15 and 12. Loveness sells clothing, a business she started in 2006. Every day she works from 9 A.M. to 4 P.M., and she earns a monthly profit of about $25.

She now hopes for a loan to buy more clothes for her business.

loans.use: To buy more clothes for her business

loans.name: Sangeeta

texts.en: Sangeeta Bibi, wife of Mr. S., has been married for five years and has one daughter and one son. Her husband runs a rented grocery shop. He has been in this profession for the last four years.. Sangeeta understands the importance of savings, therefore she regularly deposits her  savings in a local bank.  Sangeeta’s husband needs to diversify the products range at his store so that he can serve a larger number of clients and therefore needs a loan.

loans.use: To diversify the product range of a grocery store

loans.name: Please Delete Group

texts.en:
Maryam is 47 and married, with four children (ages 20, 14, 12, and 7). She sells charcoal and coconut beginning at 8:30am each morning. From this business, which started 4 years ago, she makes a monthly profit of about $35.

Maryam hopes for a loan to purchase more charcoal and coconuts to sell. She will share this loan with her subgroup, whose members belong to loan group Wema. These members guarantee one another in paying back their loans.

loans.use: To buy more inventory of charcoal and coconuts

loans.name: Shakeela

texts.en:
Shakeela Bibi, wife of Mr. S. J., has been married for 15 years. She is a graduate, and her husband has a master’s degree. Shakeela has three children--two daughters and one son--all of whom are enrolled in school. S. works in a bank in Sargodha, a small city of Pakistan. Shakeela imports bridal dresses from a few of her family members who are well settled abroad. She rents these dresses at a nominal price. Shakeela also makes jewelry, flower bouquets, and crowns for babies. Her children help her in her work.

Shakeela requires a loan to buy more bridal dresses for her inventory, thereby expanding her business.

loans.use: Expand the inventory of a  bridal dress rental business

loans.name: Razia

texts.en: Razia Bibi, wife of Mr. P., has been married for 25 years and has five daughters. The eldest and the next to her are married and the remaining three are acquiring an education. Mr. P. drives a rented rickshaw and Razia has a shop of video games. She has hired an employee to look after the shop and games in her absence. Razia herself operates and looks after a canteen in a local school, which she has done for the past 15 years. She needs a loan to improve her games store and canteen.

loans.use: Improve game store and canteen condition

loans.name: Isturah

texts.id:
Ms. Isturah profession is a Food chips seller. Every day, Isturah has to go to the market at 06:00 AM to buy ingredients to make chips like flour, peanuts and chicken intestines. Usually she bought abaut 8 kgs (17.2 lbs) for Rp7000 (about 90 US cents)/kg. Afterwards with Mohammad Najib, her husband's help, Isturah fried those chips, and after being packed offered to food stalls and cantines around her home in Kartini street, Denpasar. Profit drom this chip sales are used to pay for children's schooling, and also for family expenses. Isturah hopes she could get this help to increase business capital

Translated from Bahasa Indonesia by Gwan Liong Ang, Kiva volunteer.

Profesi yang dijalani Ibu Isturah sekarang ini adalah sebagai penjual krupuk. Setiap hari, Isturah sudah harus ke pasar pukul 06.00 pagi untuk membeli bahan-bahan untuk membuat krupuk berupa tepung, kacang dan usus ayam. Biasanya dia membeli sebanyak 8 kg dengan per kg Rp.7.000.- Setelah itu, dibantu oleh suaminya Mohammad Najib, Isturah menggoreng krupuk tersebut dan setelah jadi kemudian dibungkus lalu diedarkan warung-warung dan kantin-kantin yang ada disekitar tempat tinggalnya di Jl.Kartini Denpasar. Keuntungan yang didapat dari berjualan krupuk dipaki sebagai biaya menyekolahkan anaknya dan juga mencukupi kebutuhan keluarga. Isturah sangat berharap mendapatkan bantuan sebagai tambahan modal usaha.

loans.use: Business capital (Modal Usaha)

loans.name: Seema

texts.en: I am Seema A. M. and I have been married for 25 years. I have lived all my life in Lahore, a famous city of Pakistan.  I have three sons and one daughter.  My elder son completed grade ten and now has a private job, and the younger son to him has run a CD shop named J.S Music Video Center for the last 4 years. My other  two children attend a local school . My husband works in the Pakistan High Court. I do not work but remain at home and complete my household chores. I request a loan for my son, who wants to expand his CD business.

loans.use: Expand the CD Business

loans.name: Neema

texts.en:
Mambo from Kyela Mbeya, Tanzania! This is 40-year-old Neema M.. She is married and has 3 children aged 8, 12 and 16. In 2003, Neema established her Café business. She is now requires a loan in order to buy more kitchen utensils. She thanks you for your support.

When you see a SELFINA entrepreneur whose business title is ‘restaurant’ or ‘café’, you may have to adjust your mental image of what that is. A local restaurant or café in Tanzania usually consists of a rough wooden table and some long, wooden benches, with the sky as a ceiling. The food is all-local; rice, ugali (a hot, sticky dough, made from maize flour), a plantain (a cooked savoury banana), all served with beans, vegetables, meat, and a variety of yummy sauces.

loans.use: To buy more kitchen utensil.

loans.name: Bushra

texts.en:
I am Bushra S.. I was married 15 years ago but unfortunately was divorced four years ago. I have three children: two daughters and one son, all of whom attend a local school. The purpose of sending them to school is to make them qualified so that they can secure their future.

My business is to sell blankets and clothing, sheets, and thermoses. I had to start this business after I was divorced to earn a living for my children. I handle my business independently and now, because I feel the need for an increased income, I have decided to expand my business. I require a loan to buy men's clothing as well as women's clothing to diversify my inventory.

loans.use: To diversify her clothing business

loans.name: Rashida

texts.en: Rashida Bibi, wife of Mr. J., has been married for the last 27 years. She used to live in a village but shifted to the big city of Lahore almost one year ago. Mr. Jaffner is a day laborer and earns only a meager income.  Nonetheless, in Lahore Rashida's family has constructed a house of their own.  She has four daughters and three sons. The eldest son, after completing  grade eleven, works as a cook. The  next son to him completed grade ten and now manufactures and sells bottle caps to various medical stores. The youngest son is in the fifth standard. At present, they need a loan for their bottle-caps manufacturing business.

loans.use: For the manufacture of bottle caps

loans.name: Asha

texts.en:
Mambo from Kyela Mbeya, Tanzania! This is 30-year-old Asha M.. She is married and has 3 children aged 5, 8 and 11. In 2008, Asha established her soap-production business. She is now requires a new loan in order to buy more advanced production facilities. She thanks you for your support.

loans.use: To buy more advanced production facilities.

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: Business Loan

loans.name: Hadiya's Nia Moja Group

texts.en:
Hadiya is a 45 year old widow with a 20 year old child. She sells fish from 7 A.M. to 10 P.M. daily. From this business, she makes a monthly profit of about $90.

Hadiya hopes for a loan to purchase more fish to sell. She will share this loan with her subgroup, whose members belong to group Nia Moja. These members guarantee one another in paying back their loans.

loans.use: To buy more fish to sell

loans.name: Kaniza

texts.en:
Kaniza Bibi has been married to A. G., a daily wage laborer, for the last 27 years. She has three sons and two daughters. Kaniza’s eldest son manufactures caps for plastic bottles and plastic gallon jugs. The next son to him is in grade eleven and the youngest is in grade five. All of Kaniza's daughters are married and are settled separately in their own houses.

The family has their own machine for manufacturing plastic bottle caps. Their profits per month are approximately $175. Now they need to purchase raw material for their business so that they can promptly fill their orders.

loans.use: To buy raw material for bottle-cap manufacture

loans.name: Tuswege

texts.en:
Mambo from Kyela Mbeya, Tanzania! This is 25-year-old Tuswege M.. She is married and has 3 children aged 3, 5 and 8. She has 6 other dependents who live with her because they are orphans. In 1997, Tuswege established her crops business. She is now requires a loan in order to buy more additional stock in bulk. She thanks you for your support.

loans.name: Parveen

texts.en:
I am Parveen Bibi, wife of Mr. M., and I have been married for the last 27 years. I have eight children: six girls and two boys. My elder daughter is married and has one child. Three of the girls run a beauty parlor and one son works with his father.

My husband runs a butcher shop for chicken meat, although he is ill and suffering from tuberculosis. He has been in this profession for the last 10 years. I make and sell embroidered clothes and bridal dresses. I need this loan to expand my husband’s chicken meat business.

loans.use: To expand a chicken butchering business

loans.name: Luth

texts.en:
Mambo from Kyela Mbeya, Tanzania! This is 33-year-old Luth M.. She is married and has 3 children aged 9,12 and 2. She has 3 dependents who live with her because they are street children. In 2002, Luth established her red palm extraction business. Luth has already received and successfully repaid 1 loan from SELFINA, and now requires a new loan in order to buy more stock of red palm in bulk. She thanks you for your support.

loans.use: To buy more stock of red palm in bulk.

loans.name: Mwatima's Umoja Group

texts.en:
Mwatima is married and takes care of her parents financially. She runs a phone business, where she sells time vouchers. She started this business in 2003 and now makes about $60 a month from her sales. She works from 7 A.M. to 6 P.M. daily.

Mwatima hopes for a loan to purchase more vouchers to sell. She will share this loan with Amina, another member of the loan group Umoja. These members guarantee one another in paying back their loans.

loans.use: To buy more phone vouchers to sell

loans.name: Khadija's Furaha Group

texts.en:
Khadija is married and has two children (ages 4 and 7). She sells used clothing, a business she started last year. She works from 9 A.M. to 6 P.M. daily and makes a monthly profit of about $18.

Khadija hopes for a loan to purchase more clothing to sell. She will be sharing this loan with Nadhira and Tatu, members of the Furaha loan group (which means "laughter" in Swahili). These members guarantee one another in paying back their loans.

loans.use: To buy more used clothing to sell

loans.name: Christina

texts.en:
Christina, age 29, is married with 3 children (ages 15, 10, and 4). She sells used clothing, a business she started in 2002. She works from 6 A.M. to 10 P.M. daily and makes a monthly profit of about $45.

Christina hopes for a loan to purchase more clothing to sell. She is a member of the Umoja Ni Nguyu loan group whose members guarantee one another in paying back their loans.

loans.use: To buy more used clothing to sell

loans.name: Twesa

texts.en:
Mambo from Kyela Mbeya, Tanzania! This is 24-year-old Twesa S.. She is married and has 1 child aged 2. In 2003, Twesa established her genge business. Twesa has already received and successfully repaid 1 loan from SELFINA, and now requires a new loan in order to buy additional stock in bulk. She thanks you for your support.

The Swahili word for this type of outside shop or stall is genge. A genge is usually a very basic structure made of wood with a tin roof, which sells general items such as onions, tomatoes, chilli, oil, rice, and dried fish. It is the kind of place local people usually send their children running to fetch something when they are in the middle of cooking the evening meal and don’t have time to go all the way to the market to buy the missing ingredient.

loans.use: To buy additional stock in bulk.

loans.name: Matrida

texts.en:
Mambo from Kyela Mbeya, Tanzania! This is 39-year-old Matrida M.. She is married and has 5 children aged between 14 and 18. She has 5 more dependents who live with her because they are orphans. In 1998, Matrida established her grocery/pub business. She is now requires a loan in order to buy more stock of beer and soft drinks. She thanks you for your support.

Her bar is a good place to chill with a beer if you manage to finish work early on a Friday afternoon. It’s the kind of place where you kick back on a plastic chair under a tree, with a local beer in hand, the aroma of roasting ‘mishikaki’ (kebabs made on an open fire) wafting around you, and talk to anyone and everyone who happens to wander by.

loans.use: To buy more stock of beer and soft drinks.

loans.name: Rahma

texts.en:
Rahma, age 36, is married and cares for three children, her 15 year old, and two other children, ages 9 and 21. She runs a small general store, a business she started in 2005. She works from 8 A.M. to 6 P.M. daily, and makes a monthly profit of about $90.

Rahma hopes for a loan to purchase more inventory for her shop. She is a member of the Tushikamane loan group whose members guarentee one another in paying back their loans.

loans.use: To buy more inventory for her general store

loans.name: Bupe

texts.en:
Mambo from kyela mbeya, Tanzania! This is 37-year-old Bupe Mwakifinange. She is married and has 3 children aged 6, 8 and 12. She has 2 dependents who live with her because are they are a neighbor's orphan family. In 2007, Bupe established her rice-selling business. She is now requires a loan in order to buy more stock of rice. She thanks you for your support.

loans.use: To buy more stock of rice.

loans.name: Hekima

texts.en:
Mambo from Kyela Mbeya, Tanzania! This is 30-year-old Hekima M.. She is not married and has 1 blessed child aged 12. She has 1 dependent who lives with her because she is a street child. In 2003, Hekima established her tailoring business. She is assisted by her. Hekima has already received and successfully repaid 1 loan from SELFINA and now requires a new loan in order to buy more stock of boutique. She thanks you for your support.

SELFINA is engaged in economic empowerment of women in Tanzania through leasing and leaseback facilitation as a practical way to achieve the economic and social emancipation of women.

loans.use: To buy more stock for the boutique.

loans.name: Phalla

texts.en: Mrs. Phalla O. is forty-nine-yeas-old. She is married and the mother of four children, two of whom are working in a garment factory while the other is a nurse at the Kampong Spue Health Care Center. The youngest is enrolled in school. Mrs. Phalla O. and her husband, Mr. Long Phan, are subsistence farmers and cultivate the rice field near their house. Previously, Mrs. Phalla O. obtained a loan from AMK to buy a pump to water her crop. In July last year, Mrs. Phalla O. got appendicitis and she went to Kampong Speu Hospital to cure that disease and this caused her unexpected expenses. For this reason, Mrs. Phalla O. now does not have enough money to fix her house so asked a loan to buy timbers to fix the walls.

loans.use: To buy timbers to fix the walls to improve the living condition.

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: To buy timbers to fix the walls to improve the living condition.

loans.name: Asha

texts.en:
Asha is a 33 year old married woman with 3 children, ages 14, 12 and 5. Asha owns a small pharmacy, which she started in 2004. Every day, she works from 8 A.M. to 9 P.M. at her business, where she earns a monthly profit of about $225.

She now hopes for a loan to buy more medicine for her pharmacy.

loans.use: To buy more medicine for her pharmacy

loans.name: Kahkinted

texts.en:
Kahkinted E. is a 50-year-old widow with six children. The challenges she has faced include the ill health of some of her children and her inability to single-handedly sponsor them in school. Her former loans from GHAPE were invested in pig farming and food crop cultivation, and the profit was used to educate her children.

Given a loan, she plans to continue in the same line of business and use the profit to pay school fees for her children in institutions of higher education.

She plans to repay the loan in 24 months. The first installment is due on the fourth month from the date of disbursement.

loans.use: Purchase of seedlings and farm equipment

loans.name: Mwantum

texts.en:
Mwantum is a 24 year old single woman. She owns a small salon, which she started in 2005. Every day, she works from 8 A.M. to 8 P.M. and she earns a monthly profit of about $250 from her sales.

She now hopes for a loan to buy more salon items for her business.

loans.use: To  buy more salon items for her business

loans.name: Nyongo

texts.en:
Nyongo, age 48, sells snacks, soap, and coconut oil to make a living. She works from 7 A.M. to noon daily and started this work 3 years ago. From this business, she makes a monthly profit of about $90.

Nyongo hopes for a loan to purchase more food items, soap, and coconut oil to sell. She belongs to a loan group whose members guarantee one another in paying back their loans.

loans.use: To buy more food items, soap, and coconut oil

loans.name: Mary

texts.en:
Born in 1946, Mama A. Mary was forced to get married at the age of 15 years to Mr. Maricus A., who was three times older than Mary, because her parents couldn't pay her school fees or meet her basic needs. She and her husband had nine children. Life was difficult. She couldn't provide for her family, pay school fees, or complete the building of their home. In 2002, she decided to join GHAPE to improve her life. Since then she has received and repaid four loans from GHAPE.

Given a loan she plans to buy seeds and cassava for the production of water fufu. She thinks she will succeed because she has experience in this business and has a ready market in Bamenda urban center.

She plans to repay her loan in 24 months. The first installment is due on the fourth month from the date of loan disbursement.

loans.use: Purchase of seeds and cassava

loans.name: Hadia's Bora Utu Group

texts.en:
Hadia, age 24, is single and takes care of 3 others (ages 20, 12, and 3). She sells sarongs and clothes door-to-door to make a living. She works from 7 A.M. to 2 P.M. daily and started this work 3 years ago. From this business, she makes a monthly profit of about $30.

Hadia hopes for a loan to purchase more sarongs and clothing to sell. She will share this loan with her subgroup, whose members belong to group Bora Utu. These members guarantee one another in paying back their loans.

loans.use: To buy more stock of sarongs and clothing

loans.name: Janet

texts.en:
Janet D. sells drinks, both alcoholic and soft. She is married and has three children. Her husband’s income is not sufficient to meet the needs of the family, so she wants to increase her income.

She is running out of stock and is asking for $425 as additional capital to buy more goods for sale.

loans.name: Firida

texts.en:
Mambo from Kyela Mbeya, Tanzania! This is 24-year-old Firida S.. She is married and has 1 child aged 4. In 2004, Firida established her genge business. She now requires a loan in order to buy more stock in bulk. She thanks you for your support.

Her bar is a good place to chill with a beer if you manage to finish work early on a Friday afternoon. It’s the kind of place where you kick back on a plastic chair under a tree with a local beer in hand, the aroma of roasting ‘mishikaki’ (kebabs made on an open fire) wafting around you, and talk to anyone and everyone who happens to wander by.

loans.use: To buy more stock in bulk.

loans.name: Getrude

texts.en:
Mambo from kyela mbeya, Tanzania! This is 32 year-old Getrude M..  She is married and has 1 child aged 9. She has 5 dependents who live with her because they are are orphans.  In 2006, Getrude established her stationery business. She is now requires a loan in order to buy more stationary stocks in bulk. She thanks you for your support.  

The foresight and insight of people who have never received any training in business management never ceases to amaze me. Stationery sales is a business where such wisdom is demonstrated, with most sellers strategically placing their shops, stalls, tables or bodies strategically near to post offices, banks, schools and universities.

loans.use: To buy more stationery stocks in bulk.

Sichana hopes for a loan to purchase more food items for to make more snacks. She will share this loan with her subgroup, whose members belong to group Mtegemee Mola. These members guarantee one another to pay back loans.

She has 5 dependents who live with her because they are street children. In 2000, Mashaka established her crops business. Mashaka has already received and successfully repaid 1 loan from SELFINA and now requires a new loan in order to buy more stock of crop in bulk. She thanks you for your support.

SELFINA is engaged in economic empowerment of women in Tanzania through leasing and leaseback facilitation as a practical way to achieve the economic and social emancipation of women.

SELFINA has taken a lead role as a pioneer of micro-credit in Tanzania through Micro-Leasing. Customs and traditions in Tanzania normally make it difficult for women to own land and assets, thus they are termed not-creditworthy by financial institutions as they lack tangible collateral assets. This leads to poor financial support, hence poor access to basic needs and services for women with low incomes.

SELFINA buys and leases equipment to women. Where a client needs working capital SELFINA buys equipment from said client, extending a loan to her, then leasing back the same equipment—a process called a sale and leaseback arrangement.

loans.use: To buy more stock of crop in bulk.

loans.name: Enissa

texts.en:
Mambo from Kyela Mbeya, Tanzania! This is 25-year-old Enissa M.. She is not married and has 1 blessed child aged 1. She has 6 dependents who live with her because they are closed relatives. In 2005, Enissa established her clothes-selling business. She is now requires a loan in order to purchase additional stock in bulk. She thanks you for your support.

Secondhand clothes journey across the oceans from America and Europe and are then washed, ironed and sold in bulk by wholesalers in Dar es Salaam to retailers who then rewash and re-iron them for sale on the streets of Dar es Salaam and the surrounding towns and villages. These clothes are becoming increasingly popular, especially among the younger generation, because they are so cheap and because of the general appeal of anything Western or modern. Many people argue that the popularity of the West’s cast-offs is damaging the local cloth and garment industry. There are many people who still appreciate the beauty of traditional Tanzanian dress, however, the growing market in used clothing and its importance to many micro-entrepreneurs cannot be denied.

loans.use: To purchase additional stock in bulk.

loans.name: Bupe

texts.en:
Mambo from Kyela Mbeya, Tanzania! This is 37-year-old Bupe N.. She is married and has 4 children aged between 9 and 20. She has 2 dependents, who live with her because are orphans. In 1990, Bupe established her charcoal business. Bupe has already received and successfully repaid 1 loan from SELFINA and now requires a loan in order to buy more additional stock in bulk. She thanks you for your support.

These small, black and dirty pieces of dry earth are important not just to charcoal sellers but to their customers who rely on charcoal to cook their meals. Many Tanzanians still use small coal pots, in which they arrange mkaa (charcoal) and add either paper, dry grass, old plastic bags or kerosene in order to light them. The fire requires constant fanning to ignite and maintain the flame, and makes cooking quite a hot and laborious task. It may not be the easiest or most environmentally friendly form of cooking, but it is the only option many people can afford.

loans.use: To buy more additional stock in bulk.

One of whom is a construction worker while one other is working in garment factory. Two are attending state school and the youngest is too young to work or study. Her husband, Hay Mul, is a house construction worker and he also helps his wife in the rice field. Last year, Mrs. Rein R. obtained $75 from AMK to buy more fertilizers to support her rice field. Now, the monsoon season is coming soon so she wants to cultivate rice. Unfortunately, she does not have enough money to buy cows to use as a draft animal. Thus, Mrs. Rein R. is requesting a loan for this purpose. On the right of the photo is her husband.

The household relies on the three children to earn money to support the family expenses. Mrs. Pheap S. has never obtained a loan from any institutes but has decided to ask for a loan to buy lumber to build her new residential house in the village.

loans.name: Maida

The Swahili word for this type of outside shop or stall is genge. A genge is usually a very basic structure made of wood with a tin roof, which sells general items such as onions, tomatoes, chilli, oil, rice, and dried fish. It is the kind of place local people usually send their children running to fetch something when they are in the middle of cooking the evening meal and don’t have time to go all the way to the market to buy the missing ingredient.

loans.use: To purchase additional stock in bulk .

texts.en:
Mambo from Kyela Mbeya, Tanzania! This is 35 year-old Maria N.. She is not married, and has 2 children aged 10 and 13. In 2003, Maria established her Café business. She now requires a loan in order to buy more kitchen utensils. She thanks you for your support.

When you see a SELFINA entrepreneur whose business title is ‘restaurant’ or ‘café’, you may have to adjust your mental image of what that is. A local restaurant or café in Tanzania usually consists of a rough wooden table and some long, wooden benches, with the sky as a ceiling. Such places don’t even appear in the Lonely Planet’s budget guide, but if you’re looking for a cheap and tasty meal and someone to have a chat with, this is the place to be. The food is all-local; rice, ugali (a hot, sticky dough, made from maize flour), a plantain (a cooked savoury banana), all served with beans, vegetables, meat, and a variety of yummy sauces.

loans.use: To buy more kitchen utensils

loans.name: Arafa

texts.en:
Arafa is 29 years old, married, and has three children (ages 2, 6 and 10). She has a business selling poultry, which she started in 2006. Everyday, she works from 5am to 8pm and earns a monthly profit of about $300 from her sales.

She is requesting a loan to buy more poultry to increase her stock.

loans.use: to buy more poultry to increase her stock

loans.name: Asha's Tupendane Group

texts.en:
Asha, 37, is married and has seven children (ages 2, 5, 9, 13, 14, 17 and 18). She runs a business selling charcoal, coconuts, and donuts. She works from 8am to 4pm daily. From this business, which she started four years ago, she is able to make a monthly profit of about $170.

Asha is requesting a loan to purchase more stock for her business. She will share this loan with her subgroup Tupendane. Subgroup members are mutuA. responsible for repayment of the loan.

loans.use: to buy more stock of coconuts, donuts, and charcoal to sell

loans.name: Mtumwa's Msimamo Group

texts.en:
Mtumwa, 42, is divorced and has seven children (ages 8, 11, 13, 22, 25, 26, 27) and three other dependents that she is caring for. She runs a jewelry and charcoal business, where she sells these items from 7am to 6pm daily. From this business, which she started 4 years ago, she is able to make a monthly profit of about $95.

Mtumwa is requesting a loan to purchase more jewelry materials and charcoal. She will share this loan with Utesi, as they are both members of the loan group Msimamo. Loan group members are mutually responsible for repayment of the loan.

loans.use: to buy more stock of jewelry and charcoal

loans.name: Matha's Baraka Group

texts.en:
Matha is 35 years old, married and has two children ages 13 and 15 years old. She owns a small salon, which she started in 2005. Everyday she works from 7am to 10pm at her business and earns a monthly profit of about $110.

She is requesting a loan to buy more salon items for her business. She will share this loan with her subgroup member Theresia, who has a cafe.

loans.use: to buy more salon items for her business

loans.name: Farida's Baraka Group

texts.en:
Farida is 30 years old, married and has a child who is 12 years old. Farida owns a small food store, which she started in 2000. Everyday, she works from 7am to 12pm at her business and earns a monthly profit of about $90 from her sales.

She is requesting a loan to buy more food items for her business. She will share this loan with her subgroup member Rukia, who also has a food store.

loans.use: to buy more food items for her business

loans.name: Sharifa's Asaakheri Group

texts.en:
Sharifa, 24, is married and has one toddler. She also takes care of of three other children (ages 16, 18, and 20). She runs a food business, which she started only three months ago. She works from 8am to noon daily and is able to make a monthly profit of about $70 from her sales.

Sharifa is requesting a loan to purchase more food items for her cafe. She will share this loan with Saida, as they are both members of loan group Asaakheri. The members of this loan group are mutually responsible for the repayment of the loan.

loans.use: to buy more food items for her small cafe

loans.name: Mashavu

texts.en:
Mashavu is married and has two grown children. She runs a business selling donut and coconuts. She sells these items from 8am to 10pm daily. From this business, which she started 2 years ago, she makes a monthly profit of about $55.

Mashavu is requesting a loan to purchase more donut ingredients and coconuts. Her loan group is named Tupendane and the members are mutually responsible for repayment of the loan.

loans.use: to buy more donut ingredients and coconuts

loans.name: Sothea

texts.en: Mrs. Sothea S. lives in the village of Trapaing Taluong in the KampongSpeu Province.  She is 44 and is the mother of six children, three of whom work in a garment factory, a third one is studying in a local school and the two youngest are at home because they too young to work or study.  Sothea S. is a farmer who cultivates a field near to the village.  Her husband, Rithy Nhim, is a construction worker and when he has free time, he uses his motorcycle to do as a motorbike taxi driver to support the household.  Mrs. S. previously obtained a loan from AMK to buy a cow for breeding purposes.  Last year a drought hurt her crop, but this year all are hopeful that it will rain more and the rice crop will be more abundant.  In order to work her field she needs to buy one more cow to plow the field; so Mrs. Sothea S. is asking for a loan to help afford it.  She thanks you in advance for the loan.

loans.use: Buy one more cow to plow the field.

loans.name: María Cristina

texts.en:
María Cristina, a proud mother of four sons and two daughters, is fifty years old and a well experienced entrepreneur who lives in the Don Gregorio community of San Cristobal. Cris – affectionately called by the women of the community – has been selling vegetables for nine years. Every day, she sets her goods on her large table in the public market and passers-by stop along the sidewalk to purchase the vegetables and fruits that this entrepreneur offers.

With her loan, María Cristina will buy more goods in order to satisfy her customers’ needs and move her business forward. The entrepreneur wants to improve her family’s lifestyle.

loans.use: To bulk-buy vegetables and fruits to move a small business forward.

loans.name: Nikutusia's Tupendane B Group

texts.en:
Nikutusia is 28 years old and is single. She owns a small general store which she started in 2006. Everyday, she works from 7am to 6pm and earns a monthly profit of about $175 from her sales.

She is requesting a loan to buy more items for her business. She will share this loan with her subgroup members: Furaha, Rose and Mary. They have businesses dealing with tailoring, food vending and charcoal sales.

loans.use: to buy more items for her business

loans.name: Matilde

texts.en:
Matilde is fifty years old, and she and her husband have five sons and three daughters, all of whom live with Mom and Dad. To supplement her family’s income, Matilde sells a collection of products such as liquid soap, perfumes, hair treatment, hand and body lotions, toilet paper and the like. Bi-weekly, she goes outside her community to Santo Domingo, the capital, to get her products. She says that people of Don Gregorio, her community, need those goods and there’s not enough suppliers offering them to the community.

With her loan, Matilde will bulk-buy products and add new items in order to allow people to meet their needs. That way, Matilde will ensure the healthiness of her business and she’ll better support her family.

loans.use: Purchase of an assortment of products such as soap, perfumes and the like.

loans.name: Mwanaisha

texts.en:
Mwanaisha, 30, is married and has four children (ages: 9 months, 3, 8, and 10). She runs a business selling chicken feed and cosmetics. She sells these items from 8am to 6pm daily. From this business, which she started only 6 months ago, she is able to make a monthly profit of about $115.

Mwanaisha is requesting a loan to purchase more stock of chicken feed and cosmetics to. Her group is named Jitahidi and the members are mutually responsible for repayment of the loan.

loans.use: to buy more stock of chicken feed and cosmetics

loans.name: Tita Regina

texts.en:
Born in 1966, Regina A. is an unemployed widow with six children. Although she attributes her unemployment to her lack of education, she is appreciative of the fact that she is alive. Her desire is to give her children love and education. She states that she feels better each time she provides something small for her kids. Her inability to get investment capital to generate income motivated her to seek a loan from GHAPE. Using her previous loans, she succeeded in providing her community a source of food, meat, and manure.

Given a loan, she plans to buy piglets, pig feed, and seedlings and to pay for labor to clear farm land and help with hoeing. This investment will increase food supply in the community and provide income to her family. She is planning to use the profits generated to sponsor her children in school and to meet the basic needs of her family.

She plans to pay her loan in 24 months. The first installment is due on the fourth month from the date of loan disbursement.

loans.use: Purchase of piglets, feed, and seedlings; labor for clearing land

loans.name: Subira's Tupendane B Group

texts.en:
Subira is 25 years old, married and has a three year old child. Subira owns a small general store, which she started in 2006. She works from 9am to 8pm everyday at her business and earns a monthly profit of about $215 from her sales.

She is requesting a loan to buy more items for her business. She will share this loan with her subgroup members Aluna, Edina and Anna. They have businesses dealing in art, beauty services and tailoring.

loans.use: to buy more items for her business

loans.name: María Gisela

texts.en:
María Gisela has been cooking for more than eight years in the Don Gregorio community of San Cristobal; her hometown. Her breakfasts and lunches are just delicious and the customers are very satisfied with her professionalism and the good quality of her dishes. María Gisela remembers that it was an uphill struggle to position herself as one of the best cooks in the community because of the rough competition. Currently, she has a well established clientele and her business keeps on growing.

With her loan, this entrepreneur will buy more chairs and tables in order to allow people to enjoy their food comfortably. María Gisela’s husband passed away four years ago, so she has to support her five children on her own.

loans.use: Purchase some tables and chairs for a small cafeteria.

loans.name: Nyagu Maah

texts.en:
Born on January 25, 1954, Pa Nyagu S. is a widower who was married to Ma Angwi Grace. Before her death they were blessed with seven children, two of whom are still below the age of fifteen years. Pa S. and his family live in a seven-room apartment in the Berejei neighborhood of Bome.

Due to circumstances beyond his control he didn't have the privilege of a basic education. His parents where poor, and worst of all they died when he was still very young because of the lack of money for medication. Motivated by the need to provide for his family and the untimely death of the wife, he joined GHAPE in 2005. Since then, he has borrowed and successfully repaid two loans and used the profit to provide for his family and pay his children's school fees.

Given a loan, he plans to buy piglets, feed, rice, soap, and fish so that his neighbors won't have to travel so far to obtain these basic items. He will use the profits to continue to educate his children and reinvest in his business. He thinks his business will succeed because he is an experienced entrepreneur.

He plans to repay his loan in 18 months. The first installment repayment shall be on the fourth month from the date of disbursement.

loans.use: Purchase of piglets , feed , rice, soap, and salt.

loans.name: Margarita

texts.en:
Margarita was born and raised in the Ochocienta community of Santo Domingo. She’s thirty-eight years old and a proud mother of five sons and two daughters. Margarita sells an assortment of tennis shoes in her community. This entrepreneur doesn’t currently own an establishment for her to sell the merchandise, but she plans on putting aside money to have a location in a few years. With her loan, Margarita will add new items to her stock so as to make her business more atractive and augment her revenue.

Margarita’s business supports the children’s education.

loans.use: Purchase of tennis shoes to restock a small business.

loans.name: Mkasi's Hatuyu Mbishwi Group

texts.en:
Mkasi, 36, is married and has five children (ages 5, 6, 6, 11 and 17). She has a business selling sarongs, bedsheets, peanut snacks, and coconuts. She sells these items from 7am to 9 pm daily. From this business, which she started 10 years ago, she is able to make a monthly profit of about $125.

Mkasi is requesting a loan to purchase more stock of goods to sell. She will share this loan with her subgroup, Hatuyu Mbishwi. These members are mutually responsible for repaying the loan.

loans.use: to buy more stock of sarongs, bedsheets, peanut snacks, and coconuts

loans.name: Mtumwa's Hatuchoki Group

texts.en:
Mtumwa, age 48, is married and has three children (ages 24, 20 and 12). She runs a business of selling coconuts, sarongs, and bedsheets, and she sells these items from 7am to 4pm daily. From this business, which she started three years ago, she is able to make a monthly profit of about $25.

Mtumwa is requesting a loan to purchase more of these items to sell. She will share this loan with Fatmo, who is her fellow member in the Hatuchoki loan group. These members share the responsibility of paying back the loan.

loans.use: to buy stock of coconuts, sarongs, and bedsheets

loans.name: Jane's Raia Mwema Group

texts.en:
Jane is single woman who takes care of 2 children, ages 4 and 5 years old. She also cares for and three other people, ages 24, 28 and 56. Jane sells soft drinks, a business she started in 2006. Everyday, she works from 7am to 9pm and can earn a monthly profit of about $10 from her sales.

She now hopes for a loan to buy more soft drinks for her business. She will share this loan with her subgroup members Bahati, Mariam, Fikira and Rose, who have businesses in charcoal, fish and clothing sales.

loans.use: to buy more soft drinks for her business

payments.comment: scheduled_repayment (late autopay posting for BRAC Tanzania - Oct 24, 2008)

loans.name: Grace

texts.en:
Grace is a married woman with 2 children, aged 12 and 8 years old. Grace is a tailor and she started her business in 2007. Everyday, she works from 8am to 7pm at her business and can earn a monthly profit of about $90 from her sales.

She now hopes for a loan to buy more tailoring items for her business.

loans.use: To buy more tailoring items for her business

loans.name: Nading

texts.en:
G. Nading has been a member of GHAPE for two years. She was motivated by some other GHAPE members to join the program after her husband’s family mistreated her. She found it difficult to care for her nine children. The situation became worse when her husband died and she had to move into an uncompleted house.

Becoming a member of GHAPE has improved her situation. She has successfully repaid a loan and was able to pay for her children’s education.

Given a loan, she plans to purchase yam seeds, corn, palm oil, bananas, and peppers for her small business. She believes the business will be successful because there is a ready market and she has experience. She plans to repay the loan in 12 months. Repayment shall commence from the date of disbursement.

loans.use: Purchase of banana, palm oil, peppers, and seeds

loans.name: Mirgasim

texts.en: Mirgasim  A. is 57-year-old married father of three living in Imishli, Azerbaijan. For the past 12 years, he has earned a living by selling spare car parts. To expand his business, he has applied for a loan of $1,200 U.S. dollars. With the money, he plans on buying machine oil that is used in foreign cars, such as Mercedes and Nissans.

loans.use: To buy more car oil for a spare parts business

loans.name: Kijakazi

texts.en:
Kijakazi, age 40, is married with four children (aged 19, 9, 3, and 1) and she also takes care of her parents financially. She runs a perfume and tobacco business, where she sells these items from 8am to 3pm daily. From this business, which she started 2 years ago, she is able to make a monthly profit of about $30.

Kijakazi hopes for a loan to purchase more perfume and tobacco to sell. She belongs to the loan group, Hatuyumbishul, whose members guarantee one another in paying back their loans.

loans.use: To buy more stock of perfume and tobacco

loans.name: Ayyub

texts.en: Ayyub Q. is  a 52-year-old farmer living in Imishli, Azerbaijan. He has lived in the same small village his entire life. For the past 12 years, he has earned a living by selling the milk and yogurt he produces from a dairy cow. To expand his business, he has applied for a loan of $1,200 U.S. dollars to purchase three calves to raise.

loans.use: To buy four calves for a small dairy farm

loans.name: Siyavush

texts.en:
Siyavush S. is a 38-year-old father of three living in the Imishli region of Azerbaijan. For nearly two decades, he has earned a living by breeding cattle for beef. Meat is a staple in the Azerbaijani diet, so Siyavush has many regular clients.

He has earned a good profit, but prices for supplies have increased dramatically recently. To expand his business and support his family, Siyavush has applied for a loan of $1,000 to purchase a dairy cow and two calves. He is confident that he will be able to repay the loan.

loans.use: To buy one dairy cow and two calves for a small cattle farm

loans.name: Khanlar

texts.en:
Khanlar S. is a 49-year-old married father of two living in the Imishli region of Azerbaijan. For the past 14 years, he has earned a living for his family by milking cows and selling dairy products.

To expand his business and better support his family's needs, Khanlar has applied for a loan of $1,200 U.S. dollars to purchase three calves. He wants to start breeding cattle for meat. Beef is a main staple of the regional diet, so Khanlar is certain that he'll be able repay the loan and improve his family's standard of living.

loans.use: Going to purchase three calves

loans.name: Zainura.

texts.ru:
Zainura H. lives in Dushanbe. She is 36 years old, is married and has 4 children. Zainura sells jewelry. She gets the jewelry she sells on loan from suppliers and has been in this business for 3 years. Zainura would like to purchase her inventory, but does not have enough money. She will use the loan in order to purchase inventory, which will increase her and her family’s profits.

Translated from Russian by Sabina Holzman, Kiva Volunteer.

Холикова Зайнура жительница города Душанбе. Замужем и имеет 4 детей. Возраст 36 лет. Занимается торговлей ювелирных изделий. Берет товар под реализацию у поставщиков. Занимается таким образом этим бизнесом уже 3 года. Хочет привезти товар на свои деньги, но у нее не хватает денег. Поэтому она запланироывала получить кредит , который сможет принести ей и ее семье дополнительный доход . Погасить кредит она сможет в течении 8 месяцев.

loans.use: Increase inventory

loans.name: Mutallim

texts.en:
Mutallim T. is a 41-year-old farmer and father of three living in Saatli, Azerbaijan. For the past eight years, he has bred cattle for meat. His three sons assist him with his business. With their profits, they have been able to build a shed on their land.

But last year, prices for many supplies rose. As a result, Mutallim has requested a loan of $1,200 U.S. dollars to purchase three calves so he can expand his business.

loans.use: To buy three calves for a cattle farm

loans.name: Saidbek

texts.ru:
Saidbek A. lives in Dushanbe. He is 48 years old, is married and has 2 children. He is a taxi driver and owns his own car which he uses for work. He has been in this business for 12 years. Saidbek’s income is only enough for food and he is not able to make a major purchase. He would like to take out a loan to purchase a bedroom set. This will allow him to create a comfortable home. Saidbek will pay back the loan over a 14 month period.

Translated from Russian by Sabina Holzman, Kiva Volunteer.

Аминов Саидбек Садриддинович проживает в городе Душанбе. Возраст 48 лет . Женат и имеет 2 детей. Занимается услугами такси. Имеет собственный автомобиль на котором он и работает. Занимается этим 12 лет. Получает доход которого хватает только на питание. Сделать крупную покупку не получается . Поэтому он хочет получить кредит для того , чтобы купить спальный гарнитур. Этим он сможет создать уют в своем доме. Погасить кредит сможет в течении 14 месяцев.

loans.use: Purchase a bedroom set

loans.name: Vusal

texts.en:
Vusal K. is only 22 years old, but he's already run a barber shop in Imishli, Azerbaijan, for four years. The money he earns from his business is the sole source of income for his family, which includes his parents and younger brothers and sisters.

He has requested a loan of $1,200 U.S. dollars to make repairs to his store and buy new equipment. He's confident that he will be able to repay it, because he has plenty of regular clients who appreciate his work. Vusual says he's very hardworking and eager to learn, and he hopes to earn more profit to support his family.

loans.use: To fund repairs and buy equipment for a barber shop

payments.comment: scheduled_repayment (late autopay posting for Aqroinvest Credit Union - Oct 23, 2008)

loans.name: Elvisa

texts.en: Elvisa was born in 1982 and is not married. She lives with her grandmother and grandfather in a small suburb of Gračanica. Elvisa works and her monthly salary is 400 KM. Her grandfather has monthly pension in the amount of 280 KM. This is Elvisa's first loan at MCO WWI in the amount of 900 KM ($725).  Elvisa will buy seeds for sowing with this loan. Her wish is to try with her own food production in order to generate more income for her family.

loans.use: To buy seeds.

loans.name: Grace

texts.en:
Grace V. owns a provision store. She is married and has three children. Her husband’s income is not sufficient to meet the needs of the family. She wants to increase her income, but she needs additional stock.

She is asking for $425 as additional capital to buy more goods for sale.

loans.use: As additional capital to buy more provisions for sale.

loans.name: Valdeta

texts.en: Veldeta was born in 1960. She is a widow. Veldeta is waiting for administrative approval for her pension.  Until that happens, she does not have any income. She has a son who works in Croatia and helps her by sending her some money on monthly basis.  This is her first loan in the amount of 600 KM ($500).  Her intention is to use it to purchase food for her livestock. She has a cow and her wish is to earn more money by selling the milk and milk products. With the money she would earn, she plans to expand her business.

loans.use: To purchase food for her livestock.

loans.name: Kessy's Group

texts.en:
Kessy E., age 39, is married with 4 children (ages 20, 18, 13 and 4). She sells rice, a business she started five years ago. She buys rice from upcountry and brings it to Dar es Salaam for selling. She travels twice a month and is able to make a monthly profit of around $488.

In the past, Kessy has taken out one previous loan from Tujijenge Tanzania to pay her children’s school fees. She hopes for a new loan to hire a go down (warehouse) for the storage of her rice. Kessy will share this loan with her subgroup members who sell meat, clothes, soft drinks, charcoal, and retail goods.

In the picture, Kessy is the first person standing on the right.

loans.use: To hire a go down (warehouse) for storing rice

loans.name: Mary

texts.en:
Mary C. owns a provision store and also sells clothing. She is married and has three children. Her husband’s income is not sufficient to meet the needs of the family. She wants to increase her income, but she is running out of stock.

She is asking for $425 additional capital to buy more goods for sale.

loans.use: As additional capital to buy more provisions for sale.

loans.name: Amida's Mshikamano Group

texts.en:
Amida is 35 years old and is a married woman with 2 children, aged 6 and 2 years old. Amida owns a small salon, which she started in 2003. Everyday, she works from 6.30am to 6pm at her business and can earn a monthly profit of about $90 from her sales.

She now hopes for a loan to buy more salon items for her business. She will share this loan with her subgroup members Fatuma, Rukia, Tatu, Khadija and Amina, who have businesses dealing in clothes sales, market sales and food sales.

loans.use: To buy more salon items for her business

loans.name: Sarah's Tegemeo Group

texts.en:
Sarah is 23 years old and is a single woman. Sarah owns a small salon, which she started in 2006. Everyday, she works from 8am to 8pm at her business and can earn a monthly profit of about $80 from her sales.

She now hopes for a loan to buy more salon items for her business. She will share this loan with her subgroup members Afsa, Farida, Baia, Yunnis and Anitha, who have businesses of a salon, shop, cafe, clothes sales and vegetables sales.

loans.use: To buy more salon items for her business

payments.comment: scheduled_repayment (late autopay posting for BRAC Tanzania - Oct 22, 2008)

loans.name: Nana

texts.en:
M. Nana is married and has two children. She prepares food for sale. The name of the food she prepares is etsew and it is commonly eaten by a tribe known as the Fante in the central and western region of Ghana. Business is doing very well and she plans increasing production.

She is asking for $325 as additional capital to buy food supplies for her food production.

loans.use: As additional capital to buy food supplies for her food production.

loans.name: Juliana's Kichangani Group

texts.en:
Juliana is 37 years old and is a married woman with 3 children, aged 15, 10 and 7 years old. Juliana is a vegetable seller, which she started doing in 2006. Everyday, she works from 8am to 6pm at her business and can earn a monthly profit of about $60 from her sales.

In the past, Juliana has taken out 1 successful loan from BRAC Tanzania, to expand her business. She now hopes for a loan to buy more vegetables for her business. She will share this loan with her subgroup member Matilda, who has a business dealing in fish sales.

loans.use: To buy more vegetables for her business

loans.name: Jamila's Ushindi Group

texts.en:
Jamila is 32 years old and is a married woman with 3 children, aged 10, 7 and 4 years old. Jamila is a clothes seller, which she started doing in 2005. Everyday, she works from 8am to 5pm at her business and can earn a monthly profit of about $70 from her sales.

In the past, Jamila has taken out 2 successful loans from BRAC Tanzania to expand her business. She now hopes for a loan to buy more clothes for her business. She will share this loan with her subgroup member Mariam, who has a business dealing in food sales.

loans.use: To buy more clothes for her business

loans.name: Fatma's Mungo Yupo Group

texts.en:
Fatma, aged 40, is divorced with nine children (aged 23, 20, 18, 16, 14, 11, and 10). She owns a stand where she makes and sells chapatis from 6am to 6pm daily. From this business, which she started 9 months ago, she is able to make a monthly profit of about $25.

Fatma hopes for a loan to purchase more food ingredients to make chapatis. She will share this loan with Sada. Both of them are members of the loan group, Mungo Yupo. These members guarantee one another in paying back their loans.

loans.use: To buy more ingredients to make chapatis

loans.name: Albina

texts.en:
Alvina is married to Justino Ortega. While Alvina attends the grocery store, Justino works in a primary school.

Both have a despensa (grocery store) in a strategic place located in Luque. They are well-known in their neighborhood and that is why people prefer their despensa rather than the competition. The products they offer include: meat, rice, sugar and others.

Despensas are a very profitable market in Paraguay since it is considered a tradition to buy thing from a despensa (grocery store).

The credit provided will be used for the purchase of products in order to expand their variety of offerings.

loans.use: Purchase of drinks, sugar, rice, meat, oil, pasta,  milk, cheese

loans.name: Nzota's Ngeta B Group

texts.en:
Nzota is 28 years old and is a married woman with 1 child, aged 6 years old. Nzota is a clothes seller, which she started doing in 2006. Everyday, she works from 7am to 5pm at her business and can earn a monthly profit of about $70 from her sales.

In the past, Nzota has taken out 2 successful loans from BRAC Tanzania to expand her business. She now hopes for a loan to buy more clothes for her business. She will share this loan with her subgroup members Asha and Mejumaa, who have businesses dealing in clothes sales and food vending.

loans.use: To buy more clothes for her business

loans.name: Janeth's Mji Mwema Group

texts.en:
Janeth is 40 years old and is a married woman with 3 children, aged 21,17 and 14 years old. Janeth owns a small grocery store, which she started in 2005. Everyday, she works from 10am to 11pm at her business and can earn a monthly profit of about $175 from her sales.

In the past, Janeth has taken out 2 successful loans from BRAC Tanzania to expand her business. She now hopes for a loan to buy more grocery items for her business. She will share this loan with her subgroup members Mwajumbe and Benadetha, who have businesses dealing in soap sales and a cafe.

loans.use: To buy more grocery items for her business

payments.comment: scheduled_repayment (late autopay posting for BRAC Tanzania - Oct 26, 2008)

loans.name: Mamwa's Safinia Group

texts.en:
Mamwa, age 21, is single and runs a charcoal business, where she sells charcoal from 6am to 6pm daily. From this business, which she started last September, she is able to make a monthly profit of about $25.

Mamwa hopes for a loan to purchase more charcoal to sell. She will share this loan with her subgroup, whose members belong to the group, Safinia. These members guarantee one another in paying back their loans.

loans.use: To buy more charcoal to sell

loans.name: Sabra's Tujiwunjane Moyo Group

texts.en:
Sabra, aged 23, is single and runs a charcoal and chapati business, where she sells these items from 6am to 6pm daily. From this business, which she started in February 2007, she is able to make a monthly profit of about $27.

Sabra hopes for a loan to purchase more charcoal and chapati ingredients. She will share this loan with her subgroup, whose members belong to the group, Tujiwunjane Moyo. These members guarantee one another in paying back their loans.

loans.use: To purchase more charcoal and chapati ingredients

loans.name: Tabu

texts.en:
Tabu is 30 years old and is a married woman with 2 children, aged 12 and 9 years old. Tabu owns a small food vendor store, which she started in 2006. Everyday, she works from 6am to 6pm at her business and can earn a monthly profit of about $50 from her sales.

In the past, Tabu has taken out 2 successful loans from BRAC Tanzania to expand her business. She now hopes for a loan to buy more food items for her business.

loans.use: To buy more food items for her business

loans.name: Asha's Tujivunjane Moyo Group

texts.en:
Asha, age 41, is married with five children (aged 8, 13, 15, 18, and 25). For a living, she makes and sells chapatis from 6am to 6pm daily. From this business, which she started July of last year, she is able to make a monthly profit of about $30.

Asha hopes for a loan to purchase more chapati ingredients. She will share this loan with her subgroup, whose members belong to the group, Tujivunjane Moyo. These members guarantee one another in paying back their loans.

loans.use: To buy chapati ingredients

payments.comment: scheduled_repayment (late autopay posting for BRAC Tanzania - Oct 23, 2008)
